conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm going to check your vital signs now. Do you have any significant medical history, take any medications, or have any allergies I should know about?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I'm pretty healthy. I was taking prenatal vitamins, but that's it. No allergies either. I've never had any major health problems.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your vital signs look good - your blood pressure is 110 over 80, heart rate is 72, breathing rate is 18, oxygen level is 99%, and temperature is normal at 98.6 degrees. That's reassuring.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, that's good I guess. But what about the bleeding? Does this mean I'm losing the baby? This is my first pregnancy and I'm just so worried.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern, and it's important that you came in to be evaluated. There can be several reasons for bleeding during early pregnancy, and some of them are not serious. The doctor will want to examine you and likely order some tests to determine what's causing the bleeding.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: What kind of tests? Will they be able to tell me if the baby is okay?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The doctor will likely want to do some blood work to check your hormone levels and blood count, and probably an ultrasound to check on the baby. These tests will give us much better information about what's happening with your pregnancy.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, I really hope everything is alright. How long will it take to get the results?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We'll get you registered and back to see the doctor as soon as possible. The blood work usually takes about an hour, and we can often do the ultrasound fairly quickly. You're stable right now, which is a good sign, and we're going to take excellent care of you.

expected.esi_rationale: One resource. The only resource this patient will require is irrigation of his eyes. A slit lamp exam is not considered a resource but is part of the physical exam of this patient.

meta.source_case_text: A 42-year-old male presents to triage with a chief complaint of "something in his right eye." He was cutting tree limbs and thinks something went into his eye. No past medical history, no allergies, no medications. On exam, his right eye is reddened and tearing. Pain is 4/10.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 4: One resource. The only resource this patient will require is irrigation of his eyes. A slit lamp exam is not considered a resource but is part of the physical exam of this patient.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Lisa, the triage nurse. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I've got something in my right eye. I was doing some yard work earlier, cutting tree limbs, and I think something flew into my eye.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see your right eye looks red and watery. When did this happen?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: About two hours ago. I tried flushing it with water at home, but I can still feel something in there and it's been bothering me ever since.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Can you tell me your age and if you have any medical conditions I should know about?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 42 years old. No medical problems, no allergies, and I don't take any medications. I'm pretty healthy overall.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good to know. On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate the pain in your eye right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's not terrible, maybe like a 4 out of 10. It's more annoying than painful - feels like there's definitely something scratchy in there.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Were you wearing any eye protection when you were cutting the tree limbs?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I wasn't wearing safety glasses. I know I should have been, but it was just a quick job. Lesson learned, I guess.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That happens to a lot of people. Can you see clearly out of that eye, or is your vision affected at all?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: My vision seems okay, it's just watery and uncomfortable. The other eye is fine.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Alright, based on what you're describing, it sounds like you likely have some debris in your eye from the tree work. We'll need to irrigate your eye to flush out any particles and then have the doctor examine it to make sure there's no damage.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That sounds right. How long do you think this will take?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Eye irrigation is usually pretty quick, and since this isn't an emergency situation, you shouldn't have too long of a wait. We'll get you taken care of.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. A 3-week-old with projectile vomiting is highly suspicious for pyloric stenosis. The infant will need, at minimum, labs to rule out electrolyte abnormalities, an ultrasound, and a surgery consult.

meta.source_case_text: "Our pediatrician told us to bring the baby to the emergency department to see a surgeon and have some tests. Every time I feed him, he vomits and it just comes flying out," reports the mother of a healthy appearing 3–week-old. "None of my other kids did this." Normal vaginal delivery. Vital signs are within normal limits.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. A 3-week-old with projectile vomiting is highly suspicious for pyloric stenosis. The infant will need, at minimum, labs to rule out electrolyte abnormalities, an ultrasound, and a surgery consult.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good morning, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses here. I see you've brought in your baby today. What brings you to the emergency department?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Hi, our pediatrician told us to bring the baby to the emergency department to see a surgeon and have some tests. I'm really worried about him.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern. Can you tell me what's been happening with your baby that prompted your pediatrician to send you here?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Every time I feed him, he vomits and it just comes flying out. It's not just normal spit-up - it's like projectile vomiting. None of my other kids did this.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That must be very concerning for you. How old is your baby?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: He's 3 weeks old. He was born normally - it was a vaginal delivery with no complications.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: When did this vomiting pattern start? Has it been happening since birth or did it develop recently?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: It started about a week ago and has been getting worse. At first I thought it was just normal baby stuff, but it's really forceful and happens after every feeding now.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see why that would be worrying. How is the baby acting otherwise? Is he alert, fussy, or lethargic?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Actually, he looks pretty healthy otherwise. He's alert when he's awake and doesn't seem to be in distress, which is part of why this is so confusing.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's helpful information. Let me check his vital signs and get his weight. Then we'll get you registered and seen by the doctor as your pediatrician recommended.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Thank you. The pediatrician mentioned something about possibly needing surgery? That has me really scared.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand that's frightening to hear. The doctors here will do a thorough evaluation first, including some tests, before determining the best course of action. Let's focus on getting him the care he needs.

expected.esi_rationale: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of a post partum hemorrhage. She tells you she is going to pass out, and her vital signs reflect her fluid volume deficit. The patient needs immediate IV access and aggressive fluid resuscitation.

meta.source_case_text: "I suddenly started bleeding and passing clots the size of oranges," reports a pale 34-year-old who is 10 days post partum. "I never did this with my other two pregnancies. Can I lie down before I pass out?" Vital signs: BP 86/40, HR 132, RR 22, SpO2 98%.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 1: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of a post partum hemorrhage. She tells you she is going to pass out, and her vital signs reflect her fluid volume deficit. The patient needs immediate IV access and aggressive fluid resuscitation.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Help me, please! I suddenly started bleeding and passing clots the size of oranges. I never did this with my other two pregnancies.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Ma'am, I can see you're very pale. Let's get you to a room immediately. When did this bleeding start?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Just about an hour ago. It came on so suddenly. Can I lie down before I pass out? I feel so dizzy and weak.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Of course, let's get you on this stretcher right away. How many days ago did you deliver your baby?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Ten days ago. Everything was normal until today. I'm so scared - this never happened with my other children.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand you're frightened. You mentioned clots the size of oranges - are you still passing large clots now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, they're huge. I've soaked through several heavy pads in the last hour. I feel like I'm going to faint.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I need to get your vital signs immediately. This is a medical emergency and we're going to take excellent care of you. How many children do you have total?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: This was my third baby. My other two pregnancies were completely normal - no bleeding like this at all.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your blood pressure is 86 over 40 and your heart rate is 132. We need to get IV access started immediately and call the doctor right away. You're experiencing postpartum hemorrhage.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Is my baby going to be okay? Am I going to be okay? I feel so weak I can barely keep my eyes open.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your baby is safe. Right now we need to focus on getting you the immediate care you need. I'm calling for the emergency response team and we're going to start fluids right away.

expected.esi_rationale: One resource. This patient will need a hand-held nebulizer treatment for her wheezing. No labs or x ray should be necessary because the patient does not have a fever.

meta.source_case_text: "I have had a cold for a few days, and today I started wheezing. When this happens, I just need one of those breathing treatments," reports a 39-year-old female with a history of asthma. T 98˚F, RR 22, HR 88, BP 130/80, SpO2 99%, No meds, no allergies.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 4: One resource. This patient will need a hand-held nebulizer treatment for her wheezing. No labs or x ray should be necessary because the patient does not have a fever.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hello, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I have had a cold for a few days, and today I started wheezing. When this happens, I just need one of those breathing treatments.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see. Do you have a history of asthma or any breathing problems?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I have asthma. I'm 39 years old. This usually happens when I get a cold - it triggers my asthma and I start wheezing.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: How long have you been wheezing today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It started this morning when I woke up. It's gotten a bit worse since then, but I know a nebulizer treatment usually helps me right away.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Are you having any trouble breathing or feeling short of breath?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: A little bit, but nothing too severe. I can still talk fine, as you can see. I just have that wheezy sound when I breathe.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Have you taken any medications today for your breathing or cold symptoms?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I don't currently take any medications. I don't have any allergies either.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Any fever or chills with this cold?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No fever that I'm aware of. Just the typical cold symptoms - stuffy nose, some congestion, and now the wheezing.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, let me get your vital signs and we'll get you seen. Can you have a seat right here?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Sure, thank you. I really appreciate you getting me in quickly.

expected.esi_rationale: High-risk situation. The recent application of a cast along with swelling of the hand and unbearable pain justifies an ESI level-2 acuity level. He may have compartment syndrome.

meta.source_case_text: "I was seen in the ED last night for my fractured wrist. The bone doctor put this cast on and told me to come back if I had any problems. As you can see, my hand is really swollen and the cast is cutting into my fingers. The pain is just unbearable." Circulation, sensation, and movement are decreased.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High-risk situation. The recent application of a cast along with swelling of the hand and unbearable pain justifies an ESI level-2 acuity level. He may have compartment syndrome.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good evening, I'm the triage nurse. What brings you back to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I was seen in the ED last night for my fractured wrist. The bone doctor put this cast on and told me to come back if I had any problems.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see you have a cast on your arm. What kind of problems are you experiencing?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: As you can see, my hand is really swollen and the cast is cutting into my fingers. The pain is just unbearable - it's so much worse than it was last night.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see significant swelling in your fingers and hand. On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate your pain right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's definitely a 10 out of 10. I couldn't sleep at all last night because of the pain, and it just keeps getting worse.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm very concerned about this level of pain and swelling. Can you move your fingers for me? Try to wiggle them or make a fist.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I can barely move them at all. They feel really stiff and numb. It's like they're not even part of my hand anymore.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Can you feel it when I touch your fingertips? I'm going to gently press on each one.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I can barely feel that. It's like everything is numb and tingly. This isn't normal, is it?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm going to check the circulation in your fingers by pressing on your fingernails. The color should return quickly when I release the pressure.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: They look really pale to me, and they've been getting colder too. Should I be worried about this?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I need to get you seen by a doctor immediately. This combination of severe pain, swelling, and decreased circulation and sensation could indicate a serious complication called compartment syndrome. I'm going to take you back right now.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Compartment syndrome? That sounds serious. I knew something wasn't right when the pain got this bad.

expected.esi_rationale: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. Studies have shown that lowering brain temperature post cardiac arrest decreases ischemic damage. This patient requires immediate lifesaving interventions to airway, breathing, circulation, and neurologic outcome. Even though the patient converted to a stable rhythm, the nurse should anticipate that additional lifesaving interventions might be necessary.

meta.source_case_text: A 58-year-old male collapsed while shoveling snow. Bystander CPR was started immediately; he was defibrillated once by the paramedics with the return of a perfusing rhythm. The hypothermic cardiac arrest protocol was initiated prehospital, and he presents with cold normal saline infusing.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 1: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. Studies have shown that lowering brain temperature post cardiac arrest decreases ischemic damage. This patient requires immediate lifesaving interventions to airway, breathing, circulation, and neurologic outcome. Even though the patient converted to a stable rhythm, the nurse should anticipate that additional lifesaving interventions might be necessary.

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Trauma bay, we're rolling in code blue status with a 58-year-old male, post-cardiac arrest. We need immediate resuscitation team standing by.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Copy that. What's the story? Give me the full report.

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Patient collapsed while shoveling snow in his driveway approximately 20 minutes ago. Neighbor witnessed the collapse and immediately started CPR.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good. How long was CPR in progress before you arrived?

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Bystander CPR was in progress for about 8 minutes before we arrived. We found him in V-fib, delivered one shock, and got return of spontaneous circulation. He converted to a stable sinus rhythm.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Excellent work. What interventions have you initiated?

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: We started the hypothermic cardiac arrest protocol in the field. He's currently receiving cold normal saline infusion through a large bore IV. We've got him intubated and on the monitor.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Perfect. What are his current vitals and neurological status?

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Blood pressure 90 over 60, heart rate 85 and regular, O2 sat 98 percent on the vent. He's sedated and intubated, but he was showing some purposeful movement before we gave the sedation.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Any medical history from the family?

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Wife says he has high blood pressure and high cholesterol, takes medications for both. No previous heart problems that she knows of. She's following behind us.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Understood. We're ready for him. Roll straight into trauma bay 1. Dr. Peterson and the code team are waiting. This patient needs immediate continuation of the hypothermia protocol and cardiac workup.

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Copy that. ETA 30 seconds. Cold saline is still running, and he remains hemodynamically stable post-ROSC.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. She will need two or more resources – laboratory tests, IV fluid, medication for her nausea, and probably a CT of her abdomen. This patient will be in your emergency department an extended period of time being evaluated. If her pain was 10/10 and she was tachycardic, the patient would meet the ESI level-2 criteria.

meta.source_case_text: "My doctor told me to come to the ED. I had a gastric bypass 3 weeks ago and have been doing fine, but today I started vomiting and having this belly pain." The patient, an obese 33-year-old female, rates her pain as 6/10. Vital signs: BP 126/70, HR 76, RR 14, T 98˚F.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. She will need two or more resources – laboratory tests, IV fluid, medication for her nausea, and probably a CT of her abdomen. This patient will be in your emergency department an extended period of time being evaluated. If her pain was 10/10 and she was tachycardic, the patient would meet the ESI level-2 criteria.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi there, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, my doctor told me to come to the ED. I had a gastric bypass surgery about 3 weeks ago and I've been doing fine until today.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see. What's been happening today that's different?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Well, I started vomiting this morning and I'm having this belly pain that I haven't had before. It's got me worried because everything was going so well with my recovery.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern, especially being so recent after surgery. Can you tell me more about the vomiting? How many times have you vomited today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I've thrown up about 4 times since this morning. It started around 8 AM and the last time was about an hour ago.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: And what about the abdominal pain? Can you describe where exactly it hurts and what it feels like?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's kind of all over my belly, but mostly in the middle and upper part. It's like a cramping, aching pain. Not sharp, but definitely uncomfortable.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain you can imagine, how would you rate your current pain level?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'd say it's about a 6 out of 10. It's definitely bothering me, but I can still function and talk normally.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. Can you confirm your age for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 33 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: And when you spoke with your doctor about these symptoms, what did they tell you?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I called the bariatric surgery office this morning, and when I described what was happening, they said I should come to the emergency department right away to get checked out. They said it could be related to the surgery.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That was the right thing to do. Let me get your vital signs checked. Are you having any other symptoms besides the vomiting and abdominal pain? Any fever, chills, difficulty swallowing, or chest pain?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No fever or chills that I've noticed. No chest pain either. I haven't really tried eating much today because I keep throwing up, but I don't think I'm having trouble swallowing.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, I've got your vital signs here. Your blood pressure is 126 over 70, heart rate is 76, respiratory rate is 14, and temperature is 98 degrees - all of those look stable.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That's good to hear. I was worried something serious was happening.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: It's understandable to be concerned, especially after recent surgery. Given your recent gastric bypass and these new symptoms, we'll need to do some tests to make sure everything is okay. This may include some blood work and possibly some imaging.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Whatever you need to do. I just want to make sure I'm healing properly and this isn't a complication.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We'll take good care of you. The doctor will want to examine you and we'll likely start an IV to help with the dehydration from vomiting, and give you something for the nausea. Please have a seat and we'll get you back to a room as soon as possible.

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. This patient is describing more than just the fatigue or anemia. This patient could be describing the classic symptoms of a low-volume but high-risk situation – peripartum cardiomyopathy, a form of cardiomyopathy that occurs in the last month of pregnancy and up to 5 months post-partum. There is a decrease in the left ventricular ejection fraction which causes congestive heart failure.

meta.source_case_text: "I had a baby 5 weeks ago, and I am just exhausted. I have seen my doctor twice, and he told me I wasn't anemic. I climb the stairs, and I am so short of breath when I get to the top that I have to sit down, and now my ankles are swollen. What do you think is wrong with me?" asks a 23-year-old obese female.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. This patient is describing more than just the fatigue or anemia. This patient could be describing the classic symptoms of a low-volume but high-risk situation – peripartum cardiomyopathy, a form of cardiomyopathy that occurs in the last month of pregnancy and up to 5 months post-partum. There is a decrease in the left ventricular ejection fraction which causes congestive heart failure.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good morning, I'm Jessica, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I'm so embarrassed to be here, but I had a baby 5 weeks ago, and I am just exhausted. I know new moms are supposed to be tired, but this feels different.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: There's nothing to be embarrassed about. Congratulations on your new baby! Can you tell me more about what's been concerning you?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Well, I've actually seen my doctor twice about this fatigue. He ran some blood work and told me I wasn't anemic, but I'm still feeling awful. What really worries me is that I climb the stairs to my bedroom, and I am so short of breath when I get to the top that I have to sit down.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That does sound concerning, especially the shortness of breath with activity. Have you noticed any other symptoms recently?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, actually. My ankles are swollen now too. I noticed it a few days ago, and it's gotten worse. I'm wondering if something is really wrong with me. What do you think is wrong with me?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can understand your concern. The combination of fatigue, shortness of breath with exertion, and ankle swelling in someone who recently gave birth needs to be evaluated promptly. How old are you?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 23. I know I'm overweight too, which my doctor mentioned might be contributing to my tiredness, but this just feels like more than that.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: When you climb those stairs, how many steps does it take before you start feeling short of breath?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's probably about 12 or 13 steps to get upstairs. I used to be able to run up them no problem, even when I was pregnant. Now I'm huffing and puffing by the time I get to the top.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's a significant change for you. Are you having any chest pain, heart palpitations, or feeling like your heart is racing?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Sometimes I do feel like my heart is beating faster, especially when I'm trying to catch my breath after the stairs. But no chest pain.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm going to get your vital signs checked right away and have the doctor see you soon. The symptoms you're describing, especially occurring after childbirth, are something we need to evaluate carefully and promptly.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Is it serious? I have a newborn at home and I can't afford to be sick right now.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concerns about your baby. The good news is that you came in to get checked out. We're going to take very good care of you and make sure we figure out what's going on so you can get back to taking care of your little one.

expected.esi_rationale: No resources. This patient will need a bedside pregnancy test before receiving medication. She may be an ESI level 4, if your institution routinely sends pregnancy tests to the lab.

meta.source_case_text: "I am so embarrassed!" An 18-year-old tells you that she had unprotected sex last night. "My friend told me to come to the hospital because there is a pill I can take to prevent pregnancy." The patient is healthy, takes no medications, and has no allergies. Vital signs: T 97˚F, HR 78, RR 16, BP 118/80.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 5: No resources. This patient will need a bedside pregnancy test before receiving medication. She may be an ESI level 4, if your institution routinely sends pregnancy tests to the lab.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good morning, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses here. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I am so embarrassed! I... well, I had unprotected sex last night and my friend told me to come to the hospital because there is a pill I can take to prevent pregnancy.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: There's no need to be embarrassed - you're being responsible by seeking care. Can you tell me how old you are?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 18. I just started college a few months ago.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, and when exactly did the unprotected intercourse occur?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It was last night, around midnight maybe? So about 10 or 11 hours ago.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good information. Are you currently taking any medications or do you have any known allergies?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No medications at all, and no allergies that I know of. I'm generally pretty healthy.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Great. Do you have any current medical conditions or take birth control pills?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, no medical conditions. I'm not on birth control - that's obviously part of the problem here.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand. Let me get your vital signs real quick. Can you tell me if you're experiencing any nausea, abdominal pain, or unusual bleeding?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, nothing like that. I feel completely normal physically, just really worried about getting pregnant.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your vital signs look good - temperature is 97 degrees, heart rate 78, respirations 16, and blood pressure 118 over 80. All within normal limits.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, that's good I guess. So can I get the morning after pill here?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Yes, emergency contraception is available. We'll need to do a quick pregnancy test first to make sure you're not already pregnant before we can give you the medication.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That makes sense. How long will this all take? I have classes later today.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: It shouldn't take too long. We'll get you set up for the pregnancy test, and once we have those results, the provider can see you and prescribe the emergency contraception if appropriate.

expected.esi_rationale: No resources. This elderly gentleman has such brittle toenails that he is no longer able to clip them himself. He requires a brief exam and an outpatient referral to a podiatrist.

meta.source_case_text: A 76-year-old male requests to see a doctor because his toenails are hard. Upon further questioning, the triage nurse ascertains that the patient is unable to cut his own toenails. He denies any breaks in the skin or signs of infection. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and uses several metered-dose inhalers. His vital signs are normal for his age.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 5: No resources. This elderly gentleman has such brittle toenails that he is no longer able to clip them himself. He requires a brief exam and an outpatient referral to a podiatrist.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses here. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hello there. Well, I know this might sound silly, but I need to see a doctor about my toenails. They've gotten so hard that I just can't cut them anymore.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's not silly at all, sir. Can you tell me your age?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 76 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. When you say your toenails are hard, can you describe what's been happening when you try to cut them?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Well, they've just gotten so thick and hard over the past year or so. I used to be able to clip them with regular nail clippers, but now I can't even make a dent in them. My wife tried to help, but even she couldn't cut through them.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand. Have you noticed any cuts, breaks in the skin around your toenails, or any signs of infection like redness, swelling, or discharge?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, nothing like that. The skin looks fine - it's just the nails themselves that are the problem. No cuts or anything infected.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good to hear. Do you have any medical conditions that I should know about?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I have COPD - chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. I use several different inhalers for my breathing.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Can you tell me which inhalers you're currently using?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I have a couple of metered-dose inhalers. One is for daily use and the other is my rescue inhaler for when my breathing gets worse.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you for that information. Let me just check your vital signs quickly.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Of course, no problem.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your vital signs all look normal for your age. Are you experiencing any pain or discomfort with your toenails right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No pain really, just frustration that I can't take care of them myself anymore. I'm hoping the doctor can either help cut them or tell me where I should go to get this taken care of properly.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. Based on the history, this patient may have acute labyrinthitis and will require two or more resources – IV fluids and an IV antiemetic.

meta.source_case_text: EMS arrives with a 42-year-old male who called 911 because of dizziness and nausea every time he tries to move. The patient states, "I feel okay when I lie perfectly still, but if I start to sit up, turn over, or move my head, the room starts to spin and I have to throw up." No past medical history. Vital signs: T 97.2˚F, RR 16, HR 90, BP 130/82, SpO2 99%. Pain 0/10.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. Based on the history, this patient may have acute labyrinthitis and will require two or more resources – IV fluids and an IV antiemetic.

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: Triage, we're bringing in a 42-year-old male who called 911 for severe dizziness and nausea. He's been like this since he woke up this morning.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. I'm Janet, the triage nurse. Sir, can you tell me what's been going on today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Well, I feel okay when I lie perfectly still like this, but if I start to sit up, turn over, or move my head, the room starts to spin and I have to throw up.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That sounds very uncomfortable. When did this start?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: This morning when I tried to get out of bed. I thought maybe I just got up too fast, but it keeps happening every time I move.

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: We had to keep him on the stretcher the whole time. Every time we tried to help him sit up for transport, he got nauseous and looked like he was going to vomit.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see. Sir, do you have any past medical history? Any chronic conditions or medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, nothing. I'm usually pretty healthy. This came out of nowhere.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Any recent illness, ear infections, or head injuries?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, nothing like that. I felt fine yesterday.

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: His vitals have been stable during transport. Temperature 97.2, respiratory rate 16, heart rate 90, blood pressure 130 over 82, and oxygen saturation 99 percent.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. Sir, are you having any pain right now on a scale of 1 to 10?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No pain at all, it's just this awful spinning sensation and nausea whenever I move. As long as I stay still, I feel okay.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Understood. Let's get you settled in and have the doctor take a look at you. This could be related to your inner ear, and we'll want to get you some medication to help with the nausea.

expected.esi_rationale: High-risk situation. Based on mechanism of injury, this patient will need rapid evaluation by the trauma team.

meta.source_case_text: This patient is the restrained driver of an SUV involved in a high-speed, multicar accident. Her only complaint is right thigh pain. She has a laceration on her left hand and an abrasion on her left knee. Vital signs: BP 110/74, HR 72, RR 16, no medications, no allergies, no past medical history.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High-risk situation. Based on mechanism of injury, this patient will need rapid evaluation by the trauma team.

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: This is a priority transport from a high-speed multi-vehicle accident on I-95. Restrained driver of an SUV, approximately 30-year-old female. Vehicle sustained significant front-end damage. Patient was conscious and alert on scene.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. We're going to get you assessed right away. Can you tell me your name?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm Sarah. I think I'm okay, but my right thigh is really hurting. I was wearing my seatbelt the whole time.

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: Patient was found ambulatory at scene, complaining primarily of right thigh pain. She has a laceration on her left hand and what appears to be an abrasion on her left knee. Vitals have been stable throughout transport.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Sarah, I can see you have some injuries to your hand and knee. On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate the pain in your right thigh?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's probably about a 6 or 7. It started hurting right after the impact. The rest of these cuts don't really hurt much.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Can you tell me exactly what happened? How fast were you going when the accident occurred?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I was going about 65 on the highway when traffic suddenly stopped. I hit my brakes but couldn't stop in time and rear-ended the car in front of me. Then I think someone hit me from behind too.

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: Scene report indicates it was a chain reaction collision involving four vehicles at highway speeds. Significant damage to multiple vehicles.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Let me get your vital signs. Do you take any medications regularly?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I don't take any medications at all. I'm pretty healthy normally.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Any allergies to medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No allergies that I know of.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Any significant past medical history or surgeries?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, nothing really. I've never had any major health problems or surgeries.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your blood pressure is 110 over 74, heart rate is 72, and respiratory rate is 16. All looking stable. Sarah, given the high-speed nature of this accident, we need to have our trauma team evaluate you thoroughly even though you're feeling relatively well right now.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Do you really think that's necessary? I feel okay except for my leg. I was wearing my seatbelt and the airbags went off.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand you feel relatively well, but with high-speed accidents like this, sometimes serious injuries aren't immediately apparent. The mechanism of injury requires us to be very thorough in our evaluation. We want to make sure there are no internal injuries we might miss.

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. This patient is not someone who should sit in your waiting room. He does not meet the criteria for ESI level 1, but he meets the criteria for ESI level 2. The patient's internal defibrillator fired for some reason and needs to be evaluated.

meta.source_case_text: "My wife called 911 because my internal defibrillator gave me a shock this morning when I was eating breakfast. Really scared me! I saw my doctor a few days ago, and he changed some of my medications. Could that be why that happened?" The patient has a significant cardiac history and reports taking multiple medications, including amiodarone. Vital signs: T 98.5˚F, RR 20, HR 90, BP 120/80.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. This patient is not someone who should sit in your waiting room. He does not meet the criteria for ESI level 1, but he meets the criteria for ESI level 2. The patient's internal defibrillator fired for some reason and needs to be evaluated.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good morning, I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. I understand you came in by ambulance today. Can you tell me what happened?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, my wife called 911 because my internal defibrillator gave me a shock this morning when I was eating breakfast. Really scared me! It felt like a really strong jolt in my chest.

conversation.speaker: wife
conversation.message: I was so frightened! He just suddenly jerked and said something shocked him. I've never seen his defibrillator go off before. I didn't know what to do, so I called 911 right away.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That must have been very scary for both of you. Can you tell me when you last saw your cardiologist and if anything has changed with your medications recently?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I saw my doctor a few days ago, and he changed some of my medications. Could that be why that happened? I have a significant cardiac history, you know. I've had heart problems for years.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: What medications are you currently taking? I need to get a complete list.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Well, I take multiple medications for my heart. I know one of them is amiodarone, and there are several others. My wife usually helps me keep track of them all.

conversation.speaker: wife
conversation.message: I have the list here in my purse. The doctor just changed the dosage on a couple of them at the last visit. Do you think that could have caused the defibrillator to go off?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's definitely something the doctor will want to investigate. Let me get your vital signs first. How are you feeling right now? Any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I feel okay now, just a little shaken up. No chest pain or anything like that. My breathing feels normal.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, your temperature is 98.5, respiratory rate is 20, heart rate is 90, and blood pressure is 120 over 80. Those all look stable. But given that your defibrillator fired, we need to get you evaluated immediately. The doctor will want to check your heart rhythm and see what caused the device to activate.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Do you think it's serious? I mean, the defibrillator did what it was supposed to do, right?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The device did work as intended, but we need to find out why it activated. This isn't something we want you waiting in the lobby for. I'm going to get you back to a room right away so the doctor can evaluate you and possibly interrogate your device to see what rhythm triggered the shock.

expected.esi_rationale: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. The history combined with the signs and symptoms indicate that this patient is probably having an MI. The "pressure" started after shoveling wet snow, and now he is nauseous and short of breath, and his skin is cool and clammy. He needs immediate IV access, the administration of medications, and external pacing pads in place.

meta.source_case_text: "Nurse, I have this pressure in my chest that started about an hour ago. I was shoveling that wet snow, and I may have overdone it," reports an obese 52-year-old male. He tells you his pain is 10 out of 10 and that he is nauseous and short of breath. His skin is cool and clammy. Vital signs: BP 86/50, HR 52 and irregular.

He needs immediate IV access, the administration of medications, and external pacing pads in place.

conversation.speaker: patient

conversation.speaker: patient

conversation.speaker: nurse

conversation.speaker: patient

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. Breast cancer can metastasize to the lungs and can cause a pleural effusion. The collection of fluid in the pleural space leads to increasing respiratory distress as evidenced by the increased respiratory rate and work of breathing.

meta.source_case_text: "My sister has metastatic breast cancer, and her doctor suggested that I bring her in today to have more fluid drained off her lungs." The fluid buildup is making it harder for her to breathe. The patient is a cachectic 42-year-old female on multiple medications. Vital signs: T 98.6˚F, RR 34, SpO2 95%, HR 92, BP 114/80.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. Breast cancer can metastasize to the lungs and can cause a pleural effusion. The collection of fluid in the pleural space leads to increasing respiratory distress as evidenced by the increased respiratory rate and work of breathing.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. How can I help you today?

conversation.speaker: sister
conversation.message: Hi, I'm here with my sister. She has metastatic breast cancer, and her doctor suggested that I bring her in today to have more fluid drained off her lungs.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand. And what's your sister's name? Can she speak with me directly?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm Maria. Yes, I can talk. It's just... it's getting harder to breathe lately.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi Maria, I can see you're having some difficulty breathing right now. Can you tell me more about how the fluid buildup is affecting you?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: The fluid buildup is making it much harder for me to breathe. It's been getting worse over the past few days. I feel like I can't get enough air in.

conversation.speaker: sister
conversation.message: Her oncologist, Dr. Martinez, said she needed to come in for another thoracentesis. This has happened a few times before.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see that you're 42 years old, is that correct Maria? And can you tell me what medications you're currently taking?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I'm 42. I'm on several medications - chemotherapy drugs, pain medication, anti-nausea meds. I have a whole list in my purse if you need it.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That would be helpful. I'm going to take your vital signs now. How long have you been dealing with the metastatic breast cancer?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: About two years now. The cancer has spread to my lungs, which is why I keep getting this fluid buildup.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you've lost quite a bit of weight. Are you able to eat and keep food down?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Not really. I don't have much appetite anymore, and sometimes the chemo makes me feel sick.

conversation.speaker: sister
conversation.message: She's gotten so thin. I'm really worried about her. The breathing has definitely gotten worse since yesterday.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your temperature is 98.6, which is normal. But I can see your breathing is quite fast - you're breathing 34 times per minute, which is higher than normal.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I feel like I have to work harder to breathe. It's exhausting.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your oxygen saturation is 95%, which is on the lower side of normal. Your heart rate is 92 and blood pressure is 114 over 80. I'm going to get you seen by a doctor right away.

conversation.speaker: sister
conversation.message: Is she going to be okay? Should we have come in sooner?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You did the right thing bringing her in today. Her breathing difficulty and the fluid buildup need immediate attention. We're going to take excellent care of her and get that fluid drained to help her breathe more comfortably.
