conversation.message: Hi, I need to speak with someone privately please. This is kind of embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Of course, let's step into a private room. I'm here to help. What brings you in today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Last night I had sex, and we used a condom but it broke. I just don't want to get pregnant. I'm really worried and I don't know what to do.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern, and you did the right thing coming in. When did this happen exactly?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It was around midnight last night, so maybe 16 hours ago? I noticed the condom was broken afterward. I've been anxious about it all day.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, that's still within the timeframe where emergency contraception can be effective. Let me get your vital signs first, and then we'll discuss your options.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Thank you. I'm just really scared. I'm only 18 and I'm not ready for this. My boyfriend and I were being careful.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your vital signs look normal - blood pressure, heart rate, temperature, and oxygen levels are all within normal limits. Before we can give you emergency contraception, we'll need to do a quick pregnancy test to make sure you're not already pregnant.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That makes sense. How does that work? And will this all be confidential?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Yes, everything is confidential. We'll do a simple urine pregnancy test here at the bedside. It only takes a few minutes. Are you having any pain, nausea, or other symptoms right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I feel fine physically. Just really anxious. When was my last period... it was about 2 weeks ago, so I think I might be around ovulation time, which makes me even more worried.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your anxiety is high, and that's completely normal in this situation. The good news is that emergency contraception is most effective when taken within 72 hours, and you're well within that window.

expected.esi_rationale: One resource. In most EDs, this patient will have a rapid strep screen sent to the lab; one resource. She is able to drink fluids and will be able to swallow pills if indicated.

meta.source_case_text: "I have a fever and a sore throat. I have finals this week, and I am scared this is strep," reports a 19-year-old college student. She is sitting at triage drinking bottled water. No past medical history, medications: birth control pills, no allergies to medications. Vital signs: T 100.6˚F, HR 88, RR 18, BP 112/76.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 4: One resource. In most EDs, this patient will have a rapid strep screen sent to the lab; one resource. She is able to drink fluids and will be able to swallow pills if indicated.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi there, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I have a fever and a sore throat. I have finals this week, and I am scared this is strep. I really can't afford to get behind on my studies right now.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand how stressful that must be with finals coming up. When did your symptoms start?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It started yesterday morning. The sore throat was mild at first, but it's gotten worse, and I woke up this morning with a fever.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see you have some water with you. Are you able to swallow liquids okay?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, I can drink water fine. It hurts a bit when I swallow, but I can do it. I've been trying to stay hydrated.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good that you're keeping up with fluids. Can you tell me your age and do you have any medical history I should know about?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 19, and I don't really have any past medical history. I'm pretty healthy overall.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Are you currently taking any medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Just birth control pills, that's it.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Do you have any known allergies to medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, no allergies that I know of.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, I'm going to take your vital signs now. Let me get your temperature first.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Sure, I definitely feel warm.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your temperature is 100.6 degrees Fahrenheit, so you do have a low-grade fever. Your heart rate is 88, respiratory rate is 18, and blood pressure is 112 over 76. All of those are within normal ranges.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, so what do you think? Could this be strep throat? I really hope we can figure this out quickly because I have a major exam tomorrow.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Based on your symptoms, strep throat is certainly a possibility. The doctor will likely want to do a rapid strep test to check for that. It's a quick test that can give us results fairly soon.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That sounds good. How long does the test usually take?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The rapid strep test typically takes about 15-20 minutes to get results. I'll get you checked in and the doctor will see you shortly to evaluate your throat and order the test.

expected.esi_rationale: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. The patient is in third-degree heart block and requires external pacing to preserve airway, breathing, and circulation.

meta.source_case_text: "This 84-year-old male passed out in the bathroom," reports the local paramedics. "When we arrived he was in a third-degree heart block with a rate in the 20s and a blood pressure in the 60s. We began externally pacing him at a rate of 60 with an MA in the 50s. He is now alert, oriented, and asking to see his wife."
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 1: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. The patient is in third-degree heart block and requires external pacing to preserve airway, breathing, and circulation.

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Incoming to triage - this 84-year-old male passed out in the bathroom at home. Family called 911 when they found him unconscious.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: What's his current status? What did you find when you arrived?

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: When we arrived he was in a third-degree heart block with a heart rate in the 20s and blood pressure in the 60s. We immediately began external pacing.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Current vitals with pacing?

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: We've got him paced at a rate of 60 with an MA in the 50s. He's responding well to the pacing - became alert and oriented during transport.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Where am I? Is my wife here? I need to see my wife.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Sir, you're at the hospital. You had a medical emergency at home and the paramedics brought you here. We're going to take excellent care of you.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I feel dizzy... what happened to me? Why is there something beeping on my chest?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You had an issue with your heart rhythm, and we're using a special device to help regulate it. Can you tell me your name and what year it is?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm Robert... Robert Johnson. It's 2024. But I really need to see my wife, please. Is she coming?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you Robert. We'll contact your family right away. Right now we need to get you back to a room immediately for cardiac monitoring and possible permanent pacing.

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: He's been stable with external pacing for the last 15 minutes, but he'll need continuous monitoring. The family is driving here now.

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. Because of the mechanism of injury and his complaints of tingling in both hands, this patient should be assigned ESI level 2. He has a cervical spine injury until proven otherwise. He is not an ESI level 1 in that he does not require immediate lifesaving interventions to prevent death. At triage, he needs to be appropriately immobilized.

meta.source_case_text: A 16-year-old male wearing a swimsuit walks into the ED. He explains that he dove into a pool, and his face struck the bottom. You notice an abrasion on his forehead and nose as he tells you that he needs to see a doctor because of tingling in both hands.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. Because of the mechanism of injury and his complaints of tingling in both hands, this patient should be assigned ESI level 2. He has a cervical spine injury until proven otherwise. He is not an ESI level 1 in that he does not require immediate lifesaving interventions to prevent death. At triage, he needs to be appropriately immobilized.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Excuse me, I need to see a doctor. I had an accident at the pool and I'm really worried about my hands.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Of course, I'm here to help. I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. I can see you're still in your swimsuit - what happened at the pool today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I was diving into the pool, and I guess I misjudged the depth. My face hit the bottom pretty hard.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you have some abrasions on your forehead and nose. Are you experiencing any pain in your head or neck?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: My face hurts where I hit it, but I'm more worried about my hands. They've been tingling ever since it happened, and it's not going away.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's very important information. Can you tell me more about this tingling? Is it in one hand or both hands?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Both hands. It started right after I hit the bottom of the pool. It feels like pins and needles, kind of like when your hand falls asleep, but it won't stop.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern. This tingling in both hands after a diving injury is something we need to take very seriously. Can you tell me your age?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 16. Is this bad? My parents are on their way, but I'm getting scared.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I want you to try to stay as still as possible right now, especially your neck and head. We're going to get you the care you need immediately. The tingling you're experiencing could be related to your neck, so we need to be very careful about how we move you.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, I'll try not to move. Will I be okay? I can still move my fingers, but the tingling is really weird.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You're doing great by telling me about these symptoms. We're going to get you properly positioned and have the doctor see you right away. This is exactly the kind of situation where we need to be very cautious and thorough.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. Based on the history, this patient will require at a minimum labs and IV antibiotics. In addition she may need a gyn consult and IV pain medication.

meta.source_case_text: A-25-year-old female presented to the emergency department because of moderate lower abdominal pain with a fever and chills. Two days ago, the patient had a therapeutic abortion at a local clinic. The patient reports minimal vaginal bleeding, Vital signs: T 100.8˚F, RR 20, HR 92, BP 118/80, SpO2 99%. Pain 5/10.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. Based on the history, this patient will require at a minimum labs and IV antibiotics. In addition she may need a gyn consult and IV pain medication.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses here. I understand you're having some abdominal pain. Can you tell me what's been going on?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I've been having moderate pain in my lower abdomen, and I've been feeling feverish with chills. It's been getting worse today.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm sorry you're feeling unwell. When did this pain and fever start?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: The pain started yesterday, but the fever and chills really picked up today. I'm concerned because I had a procedure done two days ago.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: What kind of procedure did you have done?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I had a therapeutic abortion at a clinic two days ago. I know they said to watch for signs of infection, and I'm worried that's what this might be.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern. Have you noticed any vaginal bleeding since the procedure?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, but it's been minimal. They told me to expect some bleeding, and it hasn't been heavy at all.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, that's helpful information. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain you can imagine, how would you rate your current abdominal pain?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'd say it's about a 5 out of 10. It's definitely uncomfortable and it's been constant.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: And can you confirm your age for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 25 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. I'm going to check your vital signs now and get you registered. Given your recent procedure and current symptoms, we'll want to have you evaluated fairly quickly.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, thank you. I was hoping it wasn't anything serious, but I felt like I should get checked out just in case.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You absolutely did the right thing coming in. Your temperature is 100.8 degrees, which confirms you do have a fever. Your other vital signs look stable - heart rate 92, blood pressure 118 over 80, respiratory rate 20, and your oxygen saturation is 99%.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: So the fever confirms there might be an infection?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: It's certainly a possibility that we need to investigate. The combination of your recent procedure, abdominal pain, and fever are symptoms we take seriously. We'll likely need to do some blood work and the doctor may want to start you on antibiotics.

expected.esi_rationale: Requires immediate lifesaving interventions. The trauma team needs to be in the trauma room and ready to aggressively manage this 17-year-old with a single gunshot wound to the left chest. He will require airway management, fluid resuscitation and, depending on the injury, a chest tube or rapid transport to the operating room.

meta.source_case_text: EMS radios in that they are in route with a 17-year-old with a single gunshot wound to the left chest. On scene the patient was alert, oriented and had a BP of 82/palp. Two large-bore IVs were immediately inserted. Two minutes prior to arrival in the ED, the patient's HR was 130 and BP was 78/palp.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 1: Requires immediate lifesaving interventions. The trauma team needs to be in the trauma room and ready to aggressively manage this 17-year-old with a single gunshot wound to the left chest. He will require airway management, fluid resuscitation and, depending on the injury, a chest tube or rapid transport to the operating room.

conversation.speaker: ems_radio
conversation.message: Emergency department, this is Unit 12. We are en route to your facility with a 17-year-old male, single gunshot wound to the left chest. ETA approximately 3 minutes.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Unit 12, this is ED receiving. What are the patient's current vitals and status?

conversation.speaker: ems_radio
conversation.message: Patient was alert and oriented on scene. Initial blood pressure was 82 systolic, palpable only. We've established two large-bore IVs and are pushing fluids. Currently monitoring vitals closely.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Copy that. What's his current respiratory status and any other injuries noted?

conversation.speaker: ems_radio
conversation.message: Breathing appears adequate but we're monitoring closely. Single penetrating wound to left chest, no other obvious injuries identified. Patient remains conscious and responsive.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Understood. We're activating the trauma team and preparing trauma bay 1. What are his most recent vitals?

conversation.speaker: ems_radio
conversation.message: Heart rate is 130, blood pressure has dropped to 78 systolic palpable only. Patient is still alert but we're concerned about his hemodynamic status.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Copy, Unit 12. Trauma team is mobilizing. Please transport immediately to trauma bay 1. We'll have the team ready for your arrival.

conversation.speaker: ems_radio
conversation.message: 10-4, proceeding to trauma bay 1. Out.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Trauma team, incoming 17-year-old male with gunshot wound to left chest, hypotensive with blood pressure 78 systolic, heart rate 130. Two large-bore IVs established. ETA 1 minute to trauma bay 1.

expected.esi_rationale: One resource. The history is suggestive of an orbital fracture. The patient will require one resource – an x ray. She will need a visual acuity check and eye evaluation, but these are not ESI resources.

meta.source_case_text: "I was at a family reunion, and we were playing baseball. One of my nephews hit the ball so hard, and I tried to catch it, missed, and it hit me right in the eye. My vision is fine. It just hurts," reports a 34-year-old healthy female. Vital signs are within normal limits. There are no obvious signs of trauma to the globe, only redness and swelling in the periorbital area. The patient denies loss of consciousness.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 4: One resource. The history is suggestive of an orbital fracture. The patient will require one resource – an x ray. She will need a visual acuity check and eye evaluation, but these are not ESI resources.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi there, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I was at a family reunion today and we were playing baseball. One of my nephews hit the ball so hard, and I tried to catch it but I missed and it hit me right in the eye.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Oh no, that sounds painful! I can see there's some swelling and redness around your eye. Are you having any vision problems?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: My vision is fine, thank you. I can see clearly out of both eyes. It just hurts where the ball hit me.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good to hear about your vision. On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate your pain right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'd say it's about a 6 or 7 out of 10. It's definitely sore and throbbing a bit.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: When the ball hit you, did you lose consciousness at all? Even for a brief moment?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I didn't lose consciousness. I was aware the whole time. Just got knocked back a bit from the impact.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, and can you tell me your age?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 34 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications regularly?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I'm pretty healthy. No medications or medical problems.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Let me check your vital signs. Can you look straight ahead for me while I examine the area around your eye?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Sure, no problem. Is it looking pretty bad? My family was pretty worried when it happened.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see some redness and swelling in the area around your eye, but I don't see any obvious injury to the eye itself. Your vital signs look normal. We'll want to have the doctor take a closer look and possibly get some imaging to make sure there's no fracture.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: A fracture? I didn't think a baseball could cause that much damage. Do you think that's likely?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: With the force of a baseball, it's possible to have damage to the bones around the eye socket. It's better to be safe and check with an x-ray. The good news is your vision is fine and you didn't lose consciousness.

expected.esi_rationale: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. The patient is presenting with signs of shock--hypotensive, tachycardic, with decreased peripheral perfusion. He has a history of HTN and is presenting with signs and symptoms that could be attributed to a dissecting aortic abdominal aneurysm. He needs immediate IV access, aggressive fluid resuscitation, and perhaps blood prior to surgery.

meta.source_case_text: A 76-year-old male is brought to the ED because of severe abdominal pain. He tells you, "It feels like someone is ripping me apart." The pain began about 30 minutes prior to admission, and he rates the intensity as 20/10. He has HTN, for which he takes a diuretic. No allergies. The patient is sitting in a wheelchair moaning in pain. His skin is cool and diaphoretic. Vital signs: HR 122, BP 88/68, RR 24, SPO2 94%.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 1: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. The patient is presenting with signs of shock--hypotensive, tachycardic, with decreased peripheral perfusion. He has a history of HTN and is presenting with signs and symptoms that could be attributed to a dissecting aortic abdominal aneurysm. He needs immediate IV access, aggressive fluid resuscitation, and perhaps blood prior to surgery.

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: We're bringing in a 76-year-old male with severe abdominal pain. Patient states pain started about 30 minutes ago, describing it as 'ripping me apart.' He's been moaning continuously during transport.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: What are his vitals?

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: Heart rate 122, blood pressure 88 over 68, respiratory rate 24, oxygen saturation 94%. Skin is cool and very diaphoretic. He looks really bad.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Sir, I'm the triage nurse. Can you tell me about your pain?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Oh God... it feels like someone is ripping me apart inside! This is the worst pain I've ever felt in my life!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate this pain?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Twenty! This is way beyond a 10! Please help me!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: When did this pain start?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: About 30 minutes ago... it just came on suddenly while I was watching TV. Nothing like this before.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I have high blood pressure... take a water pill for it. That's all. No allergies to anything.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: This patient needs to go straight back. Possible AAA rupture. Get the trauma team and call surgery.

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: Should we move him to the resuscitation bay?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Yes, immediately. We need large bore IVs, type and cross for blood, and get the surgeon down here now.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. Abdominal pain and vomiting post gastric bypass needs to be evaluated. This patient needs labs, IV, antiemetics, and a CT.

meta.source_case_text: The patient states that she is 6 weeks post laparoscopic gastric bypass. Two days ago, she began to have abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting of pureed food. She reports a decrease in her fluid intake and not being able to take her supplements because of vomiting. Vital signs: T 97.8˚F, RR 20, HR 90, BP 110/70, SpO2 99%. Pain 4/10.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. Abdominal pain and vomiting post gastric bypass needs to be evaluated. This patient needs labs, IV, antiemetics, and a CT.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hello, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I'm having some pretty bad stomach pain and I can't keep anything down. I had gastric bypass surgery about six weeks ago.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm sorry to hear you're feeling unwell. When did these symptoms start?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It started about two days ago. At first I thought it was just normal post-surgery stuff, but it's gotten worse.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Can you describe the abdominal pain for me? Where is it located and what does it feel like?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's kind of all over my stomach area, but more on the upper part. It's like a cramping, aching pain that comes and goes.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain imaginable, how would you rate your current pain?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Right now it's about a 4 out of 10, but it was worse earlier when I tried to eat.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You mentioned not being able to keep anything down. Are you experiencing nausea and vomiting?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, definitely. I've been throwing up pretty much everything I try to eat. Even the pureed foods that I'm supposed to be eating at this stage.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That must be very concerning, especially after your recent surgery. How has your fluid intake been?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Not good at all. I've been trying to drink water and protein shakes, but I can't keep much down. I'm probably getting less than half of what I should be drinking.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Are you able to take your prescribed vitamins and supplements?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, that's another problem. Every time I try to take my supplements, I just throw them up. I haven't been able to keep them down for the past two days.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand. Let me get your vital signs. Can you tell me your age and when exactly was your gastric bypass surgery?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 34 years old, and the surgery was exactly six weeks ago today. It was laparoscopic gastric bypass.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. I'm going to check your temperature, blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen levels now.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, sure. Should I be worried? I mean, is this normal after surgery?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your temperature is 97.8 degrees, blood pressure 110 over 70, heart rate is 90, respiratory rate 20, and oxygen saturation is 99%. Given your recent surgery and these symptoms, we definitely want to have the doctor evaluate you thoroughly.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, that's what I was hoping. I've been worried something might be wrong with the surgery site or something.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your concerns are completely valid. Persistent vomiting and abdominal pain after gastric bypass surgery need to be taken seriously. The doctor will likely want to run some tests to make sure everything is healing properly.

expected.esi_rationale: One resource. This patient is seeking help finding a detoxification program that will help her. She is not a danger to herself or others. The social worker or psychiatric counselor should be consulted to assist her. Once a placement has been found, she can be discharged from the emergency department and can get herself to the outpatient program. If your social worker or psychiatric counselor requires a urine toxicology or other lab work, the patient will require two or more resources and then meet ESI level-3 criteria.

meta.source_case_text: A 26-year-old female walks into the triage room and tells you she needs to go into detox again. She has been clean for 18 months but started using heroin again 2 weeks ago when her boyfriend broke up with her. She had called several detox centers but was having no luck finding a bed. She denies suicidal or homicidal ideation. She is calm and cooperative.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 4: One resource. This patient is seeking help finding a detoxification program that will help her. She is not a danger to herself or others. The social worker or psychiatric counselor should be consulted to assist her. Once a placement has been found, she can be discharged from the emergency department and can get herself to the outpatient program. If your social worker or psychiatric counselor requires a urine toxicology or other lab work, the patient will require two or more resources and then meet ESI level-3 criteria.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon. I'm Sarah, the triage nurse. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi. I need to go into detox again. I've been trying to find a bed at detox centers but I'm having no luck.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see. Can you tell me a bit about your situation? When did you last use substances?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I was clean for 18 months, but I started using heroin again about 2 weeks ago when my boyfriend broke up with me. I know I need help.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That must have been really difficult for you. I'm glad you're seeking help. Have you been having any thoughts of hurting yourself or anyone else?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, nothing like that. I just want to get clean again. I know I can do it - I did it before. I just need to find a program that has space.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good to hear. You seem calm and cooperative, which shows you're really committed to getting better. Have you called any specific detox centers?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I've called several but they're all full or have waiting lists. I didn't know where else to turn, so I came here hoping you could help me find something.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We can definitely help connect you with resources. Let me get our social worker involved - they specialize in finding placement for detox programs and can help coordinate your care.

conversation.speaker: patient

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. Voice changes, fever, difficulty swallowing, and swelling on one side of the throat can be signs of a peritonsilar abscess. The patient needs to be monitored closely for increasing airway compromise and respiratory distress.

meta.source_case_text: "My throat is on fire," reports a 19-year-old female. It started a couple of days ago, and it just keeps getting worse. Now I can barely swallow, and my friends say my voice is different. I looked in the mirror, and I have this big swelling on one side of my throat." No past medical history , no meds, no allergies. Vital signs: T 101.6˚F, RR24, HR 92, BP 122/80, SpO2 100% on room air.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. Voice changes, fever, difficulty swallowing, and swelling on one side of the throat can be signs of a peritonsilar abscess. The patient needs to be monitored closely for increasing airway compromise and respiratory distress.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good evening, I'm Jennifer, your triage nurse. What brings you to the emergency department tonight?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: My throat is on fire. It's been getting worse and worse over the past couple of days.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can hear that your voice sounds a bit different. When did you first notice the throat pain?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It started a couple of days ago, but it just keeps getting worse. Now I can barely swallow anything.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You mentioned difficulty swallowing - are you having trouble with liquids, solids, or both?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Both, really. Even swallowing my own saliva hurts so much. And my friends have been telling me my voice sounds different too.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Have you been able to look at your throat in a mirror? Did you notice anything unusual?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I looked earlier and I have this big swelling on one side of my throat. It looks really swollen compared to the other side.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's important information. Are you having any difficulty breathing or feeling short of breath?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Not really short of breath, but it feels like my throat is getting tighter.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Have you had any fever or chills?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I've been feeling really warm and had chills earlier today.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Can you tell me your age and if you have any medical conditions or take any medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 19 years old. I don't have any medical problems and I'm not on any medications. No allergies either.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. I'm going to take your vital signs now and get you seen by a doctor right away. This type of throat swelling needs immediate attention.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Is it serious? I'm getting worried about how much worse it's gotten.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We're going to take very good care of you. Your temperature is elevated at 101.6 degrees, and with the symptoms you're describing, we need to monitor you closely to make sure your airway stays clear.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. This patient has a complex medical history and presented with an infected hand. expected.esi_rationale: High risk. This patient is experiencing delusions and may have a past medical history of schizophrenia or other mental illness, or he may be under the influence of drugs. Regardless, the major concern is patient and staff safety. He needs to be taken to a safe, secure area and monitored closely.

meta.source_case_text: Police escort a disheveled 23-year-old handcuffed male into the triage area. The police report that the patient had been standing in the middle of traffic on the local highway screaming about the end of the world. The patient claims that he had been sent from Mars as the savior of the world. He refuses to answer questions or allow you to take vital signs.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. This patient is experiencing delusions and may have a past medical history of schizophrenia or other mental illness, or he may be under the influence of drugs. Regardless, the major concern is patient and staff safety. He needs to be taken to a safe, secure area and monitored closely.

conversation.speaker: police_officer
conversation.message: We have a 23-year-old male here that we found standing in the middle of Highway 95 around 2 AM. He was screaming at traffic, completely oblivious to the danger. Had to shut down the highway for about 15 minutes to get him out safely.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm the triage nurse here. Can you tell me more about his behavior when you approached him?

He's been talking nonstop about being some kind of savior. We had to restrain him for transport - he was completely uncooperative.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: You don't understand! The messages are coming through the highway lights! I have to warn everyone before it's too late! The Martian council sent me here specifically for this moment!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Sir, I'm here to help you. Can you tell me your name and how old you are?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Names are earthly constructs! I am the chosen messenger! You cannot comprehend my true identity! The cosmic alignment is happening NOW!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you're very upset. I need to check your vital signs to make sure you're okay. Will you let me take your blood pressure?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: NO! Your instruments will interfere with my telepathic connection to the mother ship! I refuse all your earthly procedures!

conversation.speaker: police_officer
conversation.message: He's been like this the whole time. Completely refuses any medical evaluation. We couldn't get any identification from him either.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Has he shown any signs of substance use? Any indication of what might have triggered this episode?

conversation.speaker: police_officer
conversation.message: Hard to say. He's disheveled, looks like he hasn't slept in days. Could be drugs, could be mental health crisis. Either way, he's clearly a danger to himself and potentially others.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: The portal is opening! Can't you see the lights? The end times prophecy is beginning! I must warn the masses before the cosmic convergence!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Sir, I understand you feel you have an important mission, but right now I'm concerned about your safety and wellbeing. We need to get you to a secure area where we can help you.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Help? I don't need your help! I need to complete my mission! Release me immediately or face the wrath of the Martian empire!

expected.esi_rationale: ESI level 5. No resources. No resources should be necessary. He will require a physical exam, but without signs of an abscess or cellulitis, this patient will be referred to a dentist. In the ED, he may be given oral medications and/or pain medication. He is not an ESI level 2, even though he rates his pain as 10/10. Based on the triage assessment, he would not be given the last open bed.

conversation.speaker: patient

expected.esi_rationale: High-risk situation. This patient has two obvious wounds, but until he is thoroughly examined in the trauma room, you can't rule out the possibility that he has another gunshot wound. The wounds on his thigh look non-life-threatening, but a bullet could have nicked a blood vessel or other structure; therefore, he meets ESI level-2 criteria. His vital signs are within normal limits, so he does not meet ESI level-1 criteria.

meta.source_case_text: A young male walks into triage and tells you that he has been shot. As he rolls up the left leg of his shorts, you notice two wounds. He tells you that he heard three shots. He is alert and responding appropriately to questions. Initial Vital signs: T 98.2˚ F, HR 78, RR 16, BP 118/80.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High-risk situation. His vital signs are within normal limits, so he does not meet ESI level-1 criteria.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Excuse me, I need help. I've been shot.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Oh my goodness, okay, I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. Can you tell me where you were shot? Are you able to walk?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, I walked in here. It's my leg. Here, let me show you.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you're rolling up your left shorts leg. How many wounds do you see there?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I can see two holes in my thigh here. They're bleeding but not too bad.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, I can see two wounds on your left thigh. Can you tell me what happened? How many shots did you hear?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I heard three shots. Three shots total. I was just walking down the street and someone started shooting.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand this must be very frightening. You said you heard three shots but we can see two wounds on your thigh. Do you feel any pain or injury anywhere else on your body?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I don't think so. I mean, I haven't really checked everywhere, but my leg is where it hurts. I can think clearly and everything.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good that you're alert and thinking clearly. On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate your pain right now?

conversation.speaker: patient

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm going to take your vital signs now and then we'll get you back to the trauma room right away. Can you tell me your age?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 23 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, your temperature is 98.2, heart rate 78, respiratory rate 16, and blood pressure 118 over 80. Those are all normal, which is good. But because of the gunshot wounds and the fact that you heard three shots, we need to get you to the trauma room immediately for a full examination to make sure there are no other injuries.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, that makes sense. I want to make sure I'm okay too.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The doctor will need to examine you thoroughly to rule out any other possible wounds or internal injuries. Even though your vital signs are stable, gunshot wounds are always high priority.

expected.esi_rationale: High risk and severe pain and distress. Abdominal pain in the elderly can be indicative of a serious medical condition, and a pain score of 10/10 is significant. The triage nurse needs to keep in mind that due to the normal changes of aging, the elderly patient may present very differently than a younger patient and is more likely to present with vague symptoms.

expected.esi_rationale: One resource. This patient will require a laceration repair. A tetanus booster is not a resource.

meta.source_case_text: "I should have paid more attention to what I was doing," states a 37-year-old carpenter who presents to the ED with a 3-centimeter laceration to his right thumb. The thumb is wrapped in a clean rag. "I know I need a tetanus shot," he tells you. BP 142/76, RR 16, T 98.6˚F.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 4: One resource. This patient will require a laceration repair. A tetanus booster is not a resource.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, well, I should have paid more attention to what I was doing. I'm a carpenter and I had an accident with my saw today.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you show me what happened? I see you have something wrapped around your hand.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, it's my right thumb. I've got it wrapped in a clean rag. I cut myself pretty good - it's about 3 centimeters long, I'd say. Been bleeding quite a bit.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, can you tell me your age and when this injury occurred?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 37, and this happened about an hour ago at the job site. My coworkers told me I should come get it looked at right away.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That was good advice. Let me take a look at the wound if you can carefully unwrap it for me.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Sure, let me unwrap it slowly. There - you can see it's a pretty deep cut right across my thumb. I know I need a tetanus shot too, I can't remember when I had my last one.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see that's a significant laceration that will definitely need to be repaired. Are you having any pain right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, it's throbbing pretty good, but it's manageable. I've had worse injuries on job sites before. Just want to make sure it heals properly so I can get back to work.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand. Let me get your vital signs and then we'll get you registered and seen by a provider. Let me check your blood pressure first.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Sounds good. I really appreciate you taking care of this quickly.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your blood pressure is 142 over 76, which is slightly elevated but probably due to the stress of the injury. Your respiratory rate is 16 and temperature is normal at 98.6 degrees.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, I'm probably a bit stressed about missing work and getting this fixed up properly.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's completely understandable. This type of laceration will need sutures to heal properly, and we'll also take care of updating your tetanus vaccination. Let me get you checked in and we'll have a provider see you shortly.

conversation.speaker: patient

conversation.speaker: nurse

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. At a minimum, this patient will require an IV with fluid, IV pain medication, and an antiemetic. Although she rates her pain as 20/10, she should not be assigned to ESI level 2. She has had the pain for 2 days, and the triage nurse can't justify giving the last open bed to this patient. The triage nurse will need to address this patient's concerns about wait time.

meta.source_case_text: "How long am I going to have to wait before I see a doctor?" asks a 27-year-old female with a migraine. The patient is well known to you and your department. She rates her pain as 20/10 and tells you that she has been like this for 2 days. She vomited twice this morning. past medical history: migraines, no allergies, medications include Fioricet.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. At a minimum, this patient will require an IV with fluid, IV pain medication, and an antiemetic. Although she rates her pain as 20/10, she should not be assigned to ESI level 2. She has had the pain for 2 days, and the triage nurse can't justify giving the last open bed to this patient. The triage nurse will need to address this patient's concerns about wait time.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: How long am I going to have to wait before I see a doctor? I really need help with this migraine.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hello again, I remember you from your previous visits. Let me get you triaged right away. Can you tell me about your current symptoms?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: This migraine is absolutely killing me. I've been dealing with this for 2 days now and it's just getting worse. The pain is unbearable.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you're in significant distress. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain imaginable, how would you rate your current pain level?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's way beyond a 10. I'd say it's a 20 out of 10. I can't even think straight, the pain is so intense.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That sounds extremely painful. Have you had any other symptoms along with the headache, like nausea or vomiting?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I've been so nauseous. I actually threw up twice this morning. I could barely keep anything down.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm sorry to hear that. Let me review your medical history - you have a history of migraines, correct? And can you remind me what medications you're currently taking?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I get migraines regularly. I'm taking Fioricet for them, but it's not helping this time at all. And I don't have any drug allergies.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: When did you last take your Fioricet, and have you tried any other treatments at home for this episode?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I took some yesterday, but like I said, it's not working. I've been in a dark room, tried ice packs, but nothing is touching this pain. That's why I'm here again.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand this is very frustrating for you. Let me get your vital signs and then we'll get you registered and get a treatment plan started. I know the wait times can be concerning when you're in this much pain.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Please, I just need someone to help me. This pain is beyond anything I've experienced before, even with my history of migraines.

expected.esi_rationale: High-risk. This 75-year-old male tried to kill himself by cutting his throat. Because of the anatomy of the neck, this type of laceration has the potential to cause airway, breathing, and/or circulation problems. At the same time, he is suicidal, and the ED needs to ensure that he does not leave or attempt to harm himself further.

meta.source_case_text: EMS arrives with a 75-year-old male with a self-inflicted 6-centimeter laceration to his neck. Bleeding is currently controlled. With tears in his eyes, the patient tells you that his wife of 56 years died last week. Health, No known drug allergies, baby ASA per day, BP 136/82, HR 74, RR 18, SpO2, 98% RA.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High-risk. This 75-year-old male tried to kill himself by cutting his throat. Because of the anatomy of the neck, this type of laceration has the potential to cause airway, breathing, and/or circulation problems. At the same time, he is suicidal, and the ED needs to ensure that he does not leave or attempt to harm himself further.

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Incoming to triage - we have a 75-year-old male with a self-inflicted laceration to the neck, approximately 6 centimeters in length. We've got bleeding controlled with direct pressure and dressing.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Understood. What are his vitals and mental status?

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Blood pressure 136 over 82, heart rate 74, respiratory rate 18, oxygen saturation 98% on room air. He's alert and oriented but appears very distressed. The wound appears to be self-inflicted.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, let's get him into trauma bay 2 immediately. Sir, I'm going to need to ask you some questions. Can you tell me your name and age?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: My name is... I'm 75 years old. I didn't mean for this to happen, I just... I can't...

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: It's okay, you're safe now. We're going to take good care of you. Can you tell me what happened today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I... I cut myself. I used a knife. My wife... she died last week. We were married for 56 years, and I just can't do this without her.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm so sorry for your loss. That must be incredibly difficult. Are you having any trouble breathing or swallowing right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I can breathe okay. It just hurts where I cut myself. The bleeding stopped though.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good. Do you have any allergies to medications that I should know about?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, no allergies. I just take a baby aspirin every day for my heart.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you for telling me that. I need to examine your neck wound now. The doctor will be in shortly, and we're going to make sure you're medically stable. We also want to help you through this difficult time.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I don't want to be a burden. I just miss her so much. Everything reminds me of her.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You're not a burden at all. Grief is incredibly painful, and what you're feeling is understandable. We have people here who can help you work through these feelings. Right now, let's focus on taking care of your physical injury, and then we'll make sure you get the support you need.

expected.esi_rationale: New onset confusion, lethargy, or disorientation. The daughter reports that her mother has a change in level of consciousness. The reason for her change in mental status may be a UTI that has advanced to bacteremia. She has an acute change in mental status and is therefore high risk.

meta.source_case_text: "My mother is just not acting herself," reports the daughter of a 72-year-old female. She is sleeping more than usual and complains that it hurts to pee." Vital signs: T 100.8˚F, HR 98, RR 22, BP 122/80. The patient responds to verbal stimuli but is disoriented to time and place.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: New onset confusion, lethargy, or disorientation. The daughter reports that her mother has a change in level of consciousness. The reason for her change in mental status may be a UTI that has advanced to bacteremia. She has an acute change in mental status and is therefore high risk.

conversation.speaker: daughter
conversation.message: Excuse me, I need help with my mother. I'm really worried about her - she's just not acting like herself at all.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What's been going on with your mother that has you concerned?

conversation.speaker: daughter
conversation.message: Well, she's 72 years old and normally she's pretty sharp and active. But for the past couple of days, she's been sleeping way more than usual - like, all the time. And when she is awake, she just seems... off.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Can you tell me more about what you mean by 'off'? Has she been confused or having trouble with her memory?

conversation.speaker: daughter
conversation.message: Yes, exactly! She keeps asking me the same questions over and over, and yesterday she didn't seem to know what day it was. And she's been complaining that it hurts when she pees.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see. That's definitely concerning. How long has she been having pain with urination?

conversation.speaker: daughter
conversation.message: She mentioned it maybe three or four days ago, but I thought it might just be normal aging stuff. But combined with how sleepy and confused she's been getting...

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You were absolutely right to bring her in. Let me get her vital signs and assess her. Ma'am, can you tell me your name?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: What? Oh... I'm... my name is... where am I?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You're at the hospital, ma'am. Do you know what day it is today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hospital? I... no, I don't know. Is it Tuesday? Am I supposed to be somewhere?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: It's okay, just rest. I'm getting your temperature now... it's reading 100.8 degrees. Your heart rate is 98, respirations 22, and blood pressure is 122 over 80.

conversation.speaker: daughter
conversation.message: She has a fever? That's not good, is it? She wasn't feeling hot when I checked on her this morning.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The fever combined with her urinary symptoms and the change in her mental status is definitely concerning. I'm going to have the doctor see her right away. This could be a urinary tract infection that's affecting her more seriously.

conversation.speaker: daughter
conversation.message: Is that why she's so confused? I've heard that UTIs can do that to older people.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You're absolutely correct. In elderly patients, UTIs can sometimes cause significant confusion and changes in mental status. We need to get her evaluated and treated quickly.

expected.esi_rationale: One resource. The patient was brought to the emergency department for a new Foley catheter – one resource. There are no other changes in her condition, and she is already on antibiotics for a UTI, so no further evaluation is needed.

meta.source_case_text: EMS arrives in the ED with a 57-year-old female with multiple sclerosis. She is bedridden, and her family provides care in the home. The family called 911 because her Foley catheter came out this morning. No other complaints. Vital signs are within normal range, currently on antibiotics for a UTI.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 4: One resource. The patient was brought to the emergency department for a new Foley catheter – one resource. There are no other changes in her condition, and she is already on antibiotics for a UTI, so no further evaluation is needed.

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Good afternoon, we're bringing in Margaret Thompson, a 57-year-old female with multiple sclerosis. Her family called us this morning because her Foley catheter came out.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. I'm Rebecca, the triage nurse. Can you give me a quick overview of her current condition?

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: She's been bedridden at home where her family provides her care. The catheter apparently came out sometime early this morning. Her daughter noticed it when she was doing her morning care routine.

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: I'm her daughter Sarah. Mom has been stable at home, but when I went to check on her this morning around 8 AM, I saw that her catheter had fallen out. We weren't sure what to do, so we called 911.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand. Has she had any other complaints today? Any pain, fever, or changes in her usual condition?

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: No, she's been her normal self otherwise. She's actually been doing better with the UTI since we started the antibiotics last week. The doctor said to finish the full course.

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Vitals have been stable throughout transport. Blood pressure 128 over 82, heart rate 76, respirations 18, oxygen saturation 98% on room air, and she's afebrile.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Mrs. Thompson, how are you feeling right now? Any discomfort or pain?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm okay, just a little embarrassed about all this fuss. I feel fine, just need my catheter put back in so I can go home.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: No need to be embarrassed at all. When did you first get the Foley catheter placed?

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: It was about three months ago when her mobility got worse with the MS progression. The doctor said it would help prevent infections and make care easier for us at home.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: And you mentioned she's currently on antibiotics for a UTI? When was that diagnosed and what antibiotic is she taking?

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: About a week ago. Her home nurse noticed some cloudiness and odor, so we took a urine sample to her primary care doctor. She's been taking Bactrim twice a day, and it seems to be helping.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Has she had any urinary output since the catheter came out this morning?

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: A little bit, but not much. We put some padding under her just in case, but she hasn't been able to empty her bladder properly since this happened.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, thank you for all that information. Let me get her registered and we'll have someone place a new Foley catheter for her today.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. Based on the history, this patient may have a cellulitis from the navel piercing. At a minimum she will require labs and IV antibiotics.

meta.source_case_text: "I got my belly button pierced a month ago and now it hurts so bad," reports a 19-year-old healthy college student who is accompanied by her roommate. conversation.message: Good evening, I'm Lisa, one of the triage nurses. What brings you in to the emergency department tonight?

conversation.message: Hi, well, I got my belly button pierced about a month ago and now it hurts so bad. I'm really worried something's wrong with it.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you're concerned about your piercing. Can you tell me more about when the pain started and what it feels like?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's been getting worse over the past few days, but today it's just terrible. It's throbbing and really tender to touch.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm going to need to take a look at the area. Can you show me your belly button piercing?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Sure, but be careful. It's really sore right there.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see that the area around your piercing is quite red and swollen. Is that discharge I'm seeing there?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, there's been some pus coming out of it. That's when I knew I really needed to come in. It's gross and I'm worried it's infected.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's definitely concerning. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain you've ever felt, how would you rate your pain right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's probably an 8 out of 10. It's really painful, especially when I move or when my clothes rub against it.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's quite significant pain. Can you confirm your age for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 19. I'm a sophomore at the university here.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: And do you have any medical conditions or take any medications regularly?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I'm pretty healthy. I don't take any medications or anything like that.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Alright, I'm going to check your vital signs now. Just relax for me.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your temperature is 100 degrees Fahrenheit, which indicates you do have a low-grade fever. Your heart rate is 74, respiratory rate is 18, blood pressure is 102 over 70, and your oxygen saturation is 100 percent.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: A fever? That's not good, is it? Does that mean it's definitely infected?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The fever along with the redness, swelling, and drainage does suggest an infection. The doctor will need to examine you thoroughly and likely order some tests.

conversation.speaker: roommate
conversation.message: Is she going to be okay? Should I call her parents or anything?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: She should be fine with proper treatment. It's good that you came in when you did. The doctor will be able to give you more specific information after the examination.

expected.esi_rationale: High-risk situation. The history of events is unclear. How did the 73-year-old gentleman get the laceration on his forehead? Did he fall? Get hit? Because of his age, presentation, and presence of alcohol, he is at risk for a number of complications.

meta.source_case_text: "Why the hell don't you just leave me alone?" yells a 73-year-old disheveled male who was brought to the ED by EMS. conversation.message: We're bringing in a 73-year-old male found sitting on the curb at 5th and Main Street. He was drinking from a bottle of vodka and has a significant forehead laceration that's actively bleeding.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: What's his level of consciousness? Any idea how he got the head injury?

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: He's oriented to person, place, and time. Glasgow Coma Scale is 14. But he's been very agitated and uncooperative. We couldn't get a clear history of what happened - he won't tell us how he got hurt.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Why the hell don't you just leave me alone? I don't need to be here!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Sir, I'm Jennifer, one of the nurses here. I can see you have a cut on your forehead that's bleeding. We need to take care of that. Can you tell me your name?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: My name's Frank... Frank Morrison. Now can you people just let me go? I was fine where I was.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Frank, I understand you don't want to be here, but that cut on your head needs medical attention. Can you tell me what happened? How did you get hurt?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I don't know... I don't remember. I was just sitting there having a drink, minding my own business.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Frank, do you know what day it is today? And can you tell me where we are right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's Tuesday... and we're at the damn hospital. Look, I'm fine. This is just a little cut.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see the laceration is about 4 centimeters long and it's still bleeding. Frank, did you fall down? Did someone hit you? It's important for us to know so we can help you properly.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I told you, I don't remember! Maybe I fell, maybe I didn't. Can I just get this bandaged up and get out of here?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Frank, I need to ask - how much have you had to drink today? And have you been taking any medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I had a few drinks, so what? That's not illegal. And no, I don't take any pills or nothing like that.

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: He had about half a bottle of vodka with him when we found him. His clothes are pretty disheveled, and there's dried blood on his shirt too.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. Frank, we're going to need to clean that wound and make sure you don't have any other injuries. The doctor will need to examine you thoroughly because head injuries can be serious, especially with alcohol involved.

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. This patient may be describing a penile fracture, a medical emergency. It is most often caused by blunt trauma to an erect penis. This patient needs to be evaluated promptly.

meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. This patient may be describing a penile fracture, a medical emergency. It is most often caused by blunt trauma to an erect penis. This patient needs to be evaluated promptly.

conversation.speaker: patient

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you're in significant distress. Can you confirm your age for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 42 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Do you take any regular medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, no medications at all.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Any known drug allergies?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No known drug allergies.

conversation.speaker: nurse

expected.esi_rationale: One resource. This young woman needs an incision and drainage of her paronychia. She will require no other resources.

meta.source_case_text: "I have this infection in my cuticle," reports a healthy 26-year-old female. "It started hurting 2 days ago, and today I noticed the pus." The patient has a small paronychia on her right second finger. No known drug allergies. T 98.8˚F, RR 14, HR 62, BP 108/70.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 4: One resource. This young woman needs an incision and drainage of her paronychia. She will require no other resources.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi there, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I have this infection in my cuticle that's been bothering me. I think I need to have someone look at it.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see. Can you tell me when this started and how it's been progressing?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Well, it started hurting about 2 days ago. At first I thought it was just a hangnail or something, but today I noticed there's actually pus coming from it.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Can you show me which finger is affected?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's this one, my right second finger. You can see it's all swollen and red around the cuticle area.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see that. It looks like you have what we call a paronychia - that's an infection around the nail bed. How would you describe your overall health? Do you have any medical conditions?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm pretty healthy overall. I'm 26 and I don't have any ongoing health issues or anything like that.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good to hear. Do you have any known allergies to medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, no drug allergies that I'm aware of.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Perfect. Let me take your vital signs to make sure everything looks good. Can you confirm your age for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I'm 26 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, your temperature is 98.8 degrees, which is just slightly elevated. Your heart rate is 62, respiratory rate is 14, and blood pressure is 108 over 70. Those are all good numbers.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That's a relief. Is the slight fever because of the infection?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: It could be related to the infection, though 98.8 is really just barely elevated. How much pain are you experiencing with this?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's uncomfortable, but it's not severe pain. Maybe like a 4 out of 10? It's more annoying than anything, and I'm worried about it getting worse.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That makes sense. Based on what I'm seeing, you have a small paronychia that will likely need to be drained by the doctor. This is a straightforward procedure, and you should feel much better afterwards.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Oh okay, so they'll need to drain the pus out? Will that hurt?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The doctor will numb the area first, so the procedure itself shouldn't be too uncomfortable. You'll probably need an incision and drainage, and then you'll likely go home with some antibiotics and instructions for care.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Alright, that sounds manageable. How long do you think I'll be here?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: For this type of issue, you shouldn't be here too long. Once the doctor sees you and does the procedure, you'll be able to head home. Let me get you registered and we'll get you back to see the doctor.

expected.esi_rationale: Severe pain and distress. The triage nurse is unable to manage his pain at triage other than applying a sling and ice. He will require IV opioids to reduce his pain and relocate his shoulder.
