conversation.message: I understand. Can you tell me your age?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 20. Please, can you give me something for the pain? This is killing me.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We're going to get you taken care of right away. Let me check your circulation and sensation in that arm. Can you wiggle your fingers for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, I can move my fingers. They feel normal, not numb or anything. But my shoulder feels like it's on fire.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good, that's important. I can feel your pulse in your wrist and your fingers are warm and pink, so your circulation looks good. I'm going to apply a sling to support your arm and get some ice for the swelling.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, thank you. How long before I can get something stronger for the pain? This sling helps a little but not much.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Let me get your vital signs quickly, and then I'll get you back to a room immediately. You're going to need IV pain medication and a doctor to relocate your shoulder.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: How long will that take? I don't know how much longer I can handle this pain.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your blood pressure and heart rate look normal despite the pain, which is good. Based on your injury and pain level, you're a high priority. We'll get you back to a treatment room right now.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Thank you so much. Will they be able to fix it today?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Yes, the doctor will need to relocate your shoulder, and with IV pain medication, you should feel much better very quickly. Let's get you back there now.

expected.esi_rationale: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. Immediate aggressive airway management is what this patient requires. Her saturation is very low, and she appears to be tiring. The triage nurse does not need the other vital signs in order to decide that this patient needs immediate care.

meta.source_case_text: A 72-year-old female with obvious chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and increased work of breathing is wheeled into triage. Between breaths, she tells you that she "is having a hard time breathing and has had a fever since yesterday." The SpO2 monitor is alarming and displaying a saturation of 79 percent.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 1: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. Immediate aggressive airway management is what this patient requires. Her saturation is very low, and she appears to be tiring. The triage nurse does not need the other vital signs in order to decide that this patient needs immediate care.

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: Help! Please help us! She can't breathe!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see she's in respiratory distress. Let's get her into the emergency bay immediately. Ma'am, I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. What's your name?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm... Dorothy... I'm having... a hard time... breathing...

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Dorothy, when did this start? Can you tell me what's been happening?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I've had... a fever... since yesterday... but this morning... I just can't... catch my breath...

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: She has COPD and she's been getting worse all night. She was using her inhaler constantly but it's not helping at all.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Dorothy, I can see you're working very hard to breathe. Your oxygen saturation is very low at 79% and the monitor is alarming. We need to get you help right now.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I feel like... I'm drowning... Can't get... enough air...

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We're going to take excellent care of you. I'm calling the doctor immediately - you need urgent breathing support. Let's get you on some oxygen right away.

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: Is she going to be okay? She's never been this bad before.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: She's in the right place now. The medical team is going to intervene immediately to help her breathing. This is our highest priority.

expected.esi_rationale: High-risk situation. Homicidal ideation is a clear high-risk situation. This patient needs to be placed in a safe, secure environment, even though he is calm and cooperative at triage.

meta.source_case_text: A 17-year-old handcuffed male walks into the ED accompanied by the police. The parents called 911 because their son was out of control: verbally and physically acting out and threatening to kill the family. He is cooperative at triage and answers your questions appropriately. He has no past medical history or allergies and is currently taking no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High-risk situation. Homicidal ideation is a clear high-risk situation. This patient needs to be placed in a safe, secure environment, even though he is calm and cooperative at triage.

conversation.speaker: police_officer
conversation.message: We're bringing in a 17-year-old male. Parents called 911 because he was completely out of control at home - verbally and physically acting out, threatening to kill his family members. He's been cooperative during transport.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you, officer. I can see he's handcuffed. How is he doing right now?

conversation.speaker: police_officer
conversation.message: He's calm now, very different from what the parents described. Been answering our questions appropriately during the ride over.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Alright. Sir, I'm Jennifer, one of the nurses here. Can you tell me your name and how old you are?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm Marcus. I'm 17 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Marcus, can you tell me what happened at home today that brought you here?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I... I got really angry. I was yelling at my parents and my sister. I said some things I shouldn't have said.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The officers mentioned there were some threats made. Can you tell me about that?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, I... I told them I was going to kill them. But I didn't mean it, I was just so mad. I wasn't actually going to do anything.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand you're feeling calmer now. Do you have any medical history I should know about? Any conditions, surgeries, or ongoing health issues?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, nothing like that. I've never really been sick or had any surgeries.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Are you allergic to any medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, no allergies that I know of.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: And are you currently taking any medications - prescription, over-the-counter, or anything else?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I don't take anything.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay Marcus, I'm going to check your vital signs now. Just stay relaxed.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your vital signs look normal - blood pressure, heart rate, breathing, and temperature are all within normal limits. How are you feeling physically right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I feel fine physically. Just... I don't know why I got so angry. That's not usually like me.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I appreciate you being cooperative and answering my questions, Marcus. We're going to make sure you get the help you need and that everyone stays safe.

expected.esi_rationale: No resources. A tetanus immunization does not count as a resource. The patient will be seen by a physician or midlevel provider and receive a tetanus immunization and discharge instructions. This patient will require no resources.

meta.source_case_text: "I think I need a tetanus shot," a 29-year-old female tells you. "I stepped on a rusty nail this morning, and I know I haven't had one for years." No past medical history, No known drug allergies, no medications.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 5: No resources. A tetanus immunization does not count as a resource. The patient will be seen by a physician or midlevel provider and receive a tetanus immunization and discharge instructions. This patient will require no resources.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good morning, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I think I need a tetanus shot. I stepped on a rusty nail this morning and I know I haven't had one for years.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see. Can you tell me a bit more about what happened? Where did this occur?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I was working in my backyard this morning, moving some old boards around, and I stepped right on this rusty nail that was sticking up. It went through my shoe and into my foot.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That sounds painful. Are you currently experiencing any pain or bleeding from the wound?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It hurt when it happened, but it's not too bad now. There was a little bit of bleeding but it stopped. I cleaned it off when I got inside.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good that you cleaned it. When was your last tetanus vaccination? Do you remember approximately?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I honestly can't remember exactly, but I know it's been several years. Maybe when I was in college? I'm 29 now, so it's been way too long.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, and can you tell me about your medical history? Do you have any ongoing health conditions or take any medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I'm pretty healthy. No past medical history, no medications, and no known drug allergies.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good to know. Based on what you've told me, it sounds like you do need an updated tetanus vaccination. We'll get you registered and have a provider see you to examine the wound and give you the tetanus shot.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Perfect, that's exactly what I was hoping for. How long do you think it'll take? I don't feel like it's an emergency or anything.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You're right, this isn't an emergency situation. It should be fairly straightforward - just an examination and the vaccination. The wait time will depend on how busy we are today, but this type of visit is usually pretty quick once you're seen.

expected.esi_rationale: One resource. This patient will be sent back to the nursing home after the feeding tube is reinserted. There is no acute change in his medical condition that warrants any further evaluation. He is unresponsive, but that is the patient's baseline mental status so he is not an ESI level 1.

meta.source_case_text: A 63-year-old cachectic male is brought in from the local nursing home because his feeding tube fell out again. The patient is usually unresponsive. He has been in the nursing home since he suffered a massive stroke about 4 years ago.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 4: One resource. This patient will be sent back to the nursing home after the feeding tube is reinserted. There is no acute change in his medical condition that warrants any further evaluation. He is unresponsive, but that is the patient's baseline mental status so he is not an ESI level 1.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Jessica, the triage nurse. I see you've brought someone in from Sunset Manor Nursing Home?

conversation.speaker: nursing_home_aide
conversation.message: Yes, this is Mr. Thompson. He's 63 years old and his feeding tube fell out again this morning. We need to get it reinserted.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see. Has this happened before with Mr. Thompson?

conversation.speaker: nursing_home_aide
conversation.message: Unfortunately, yes. This is probably the third time in the past six months. He tends to pull at it sometimes, even though he's usually unresponsive.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Can you tell me about his baseline condition and medical history?

conversation.speaker: nursing_home_aide
conversation.message: He's been with us for about 4 years now, ever since he had a massive stroke. He's usually unresponsive - this is his normal state. He's quite cachectic, as you can see, which is why the feeding tube is so important for his nutrition.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Any changes in his condition today? Fever, increased agitation, any signs of distress?

conversation.speaker: nursing_home_aide
conversation.message: No, nothing different from his baseline. No fever, no signs of infection around the tube site. He's been the same as always - just needs the tube put back in so we can continue his feedings.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, and when did you last notice the tube was out?

conversation.speaker: nursing_home_aide
conversation.message: We discovered it during his 8 AM feeding this morning. The night staff said it was still in place during the overnight check, so it probably came out sometime early this morning.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Alright, I'll get him registered and have the physician take a look to get that feeding tube reinserted. You can stay with him if you'd like.

expected.esi_rationale: High-risk situation for allergic reaction. The patient has used his EpiPen but still requires additional medications and close monitoring.

meta.source_case_text: A 28-year-old male presents to the ED requesting to be checked. He has a severe shellfish allergy and mistakenly ate a dip that contained shrimp. He immediately felt his throat start to close, so he used his EpiPen. He tells you that he feels okay. No wheezes or rash noted. Vital signs: BP 136/84, HR 108, RR 20, SpO2 97%, T 97˚F.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High-risk situation for allergic reaction. The patient has used his EpiPen but still requires additional medications and close monitoring.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hello, I'm Jessica, the triage nurse. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I need to be checked out. I have a severe shellfish allergy and I accidentally ate something that had shrimp in it.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Oh my, that sounds serious. When did this happen and what symptoms did you experience?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It was about 20 minutes ago. I was at a party and tried this dip - didn't know it had shrimp in it. Almost immediately I felt my throat starting to close up.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That must have been frightening. Do you carry an EpiPen with you?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I always do. I used it right away when I felt my throat tightening. I think it helped because I'm feeling okay now.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good thinking using your EpiPen immediately. Even though you're feeling better, it's important we evaluate you. Are you experiencing any difficulty breathing, wheezing, or shortness of breath right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, my breathing feels normal now. The throat tightness went away after I used the EpiPen.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good to hear. Are you having any itching, hives, or rash anywhere on your body?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I don't see any rash or feel any itching. I think the EpiPen caught it in time.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Let me get your vital signs and do a quick assessment. Can you confirm your age for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 28 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. I'm going to listen to your lungs and check your vital signs now.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your lungs sound clear - no wheezing. Your blood pressure is 136 over 84, heart rate is 108, respiratory rate 20, oxygen saturation 97%, and temperature is normal at 97 degrees.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: So everything looks okay then? Can I go home?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: While you're feeling better now, allergic reactions like yours can be unpredictable. Sometimes there can be a second wave of symptoms even after using an EpiPen. We need to monitor you closely and the doctor may want to give you additional medications.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I didn't know that could happen. How long do I need to stay?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Typically we observe patients for several hours after a reaction like this, especially since you needed your EpiPen. The doctor will assess you and determine the best treatment plan. This is definitely the right place for you to be.

expected.esi_rationale: No resources. A physical exam and providing the mother with reassurance and education is what this 18-month-old will require. His activity level is appropriate, and he is taking fluids by mouth.

meta.source_case_text: You are trying to triage an 18-month-old whose mother brought him in for vomiting. The toddler is very active and trying to get off his mother's lap. To distract him, the mother hands him a bottle of juice, which he immediately begins sucking on. The child looks well hydrated and is afebrile.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 5: No resources. A physical exam and providing the mother with reassurance and education is what this 18-month-old will require. His activity level is appropriate, and he is taking fluids by mouth.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi there! I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. I see you've brought your little one in today. What's been going on?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Hi, yes, this is my 18-month-old son. He's been vomiting today and I'm just worried about him. Come here, sweetie, stay on mama's lap.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see he's quite active! How long has he been vomiting, and how many times would you say?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: It started this morning, maybe around 8 AM. He's thrown up maybe 3 or 4 times. But look at him now - he won't sit still! Here honey, have some juice.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see he's taking that juice bottle really well. Has he been able to keep fluids down, or is he vomiting everything?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Actually, he's been drinking okay. The juice stays down, and he had some water earlier too. He just keeps wanting to get down and run around.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's actually a really good sign that he's staying hydrated. Has he had any fever today?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: No, no fever at all. I checked his temperature before we came in and it was normal. He's just his usual energetic self, which is why I wasn't sure if I should bring him in.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You did the right thing checking on him. I can see he looks well hydrated - his skin looks good, he's alert and active. Any other symptoms? Diarrhea, unusual crying, anything like that?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: No diarrhea, and honestly he's been in a pretty good mood considering. He was playing with his toys this morning between the vomiting episodes. I just worry because he's so little.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's completely understandable - you're being a good mom by bringing him in. The fact that he's drinking fluids, has no fever, and is this active are all very reassuring signs.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. A laceration through the vermilion border requires the physician to line up the edges exactly. Misalignment can be noticeable. A healthy 19-month-old will probably not cooperate. In most settings, he will require conscious sedation, which counts as two resources. The toddler's vital signs are within normal limits for his age, so there is no reason to up-triage to ESI level 2.

meta.source_case_text: "He was running after his brother, fell, and cut his lip on the corner of the coffee table. There was blood everywhere," recalls the mother of a healthy 19-month-old. "He'll never stay still for the doctor." You notice that the baby has a 2-centimeter lip laceration that extends through the vermilion border. Vital signs are within normal limits for age.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. A laceration through the vermilion border requires the physician to line up the edges exactly. Misalignment can be noticeable. A healthy 19-month-old will probably not cooperate. In most settings, he will require conscious sedation, which counts as two resources. The toddler's vital signs are within normal limits for his age, so there is no reason to up-triage to ESI level 2.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hello, I'm Linda, the triage nurse. I can see you have a little one with you. What happened today?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Hi, yes, this is my son Tommy. He was running after his older brother and fell. He cut his lip on the corner of our coffee table. There was blood everywhere - it scared me so much!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Oh my, that must have been frightening for both of you. How old is Tommy?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: He's 19 months old. He's usually such a good little guy, but he was trying to keep up with his 4-year-old brother and just couldn't stop in time.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand. Let me take a look at his lip. Tommy, can you let me see? Oh, I can see there's a laceration here. Mom, when did this happen?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: About an hour ago. I got the bleeding to stop mostly, but I could see it was deep and goes right through the edge of his lip. I know that's not good.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You did the right thing bringing him in. I can see this cut goes through what we call the vermilion border - that's the edge between the lip and skin. How has he been acting since it happened?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: He cried a lot at first, but he's calmed down now. He's still fussy though, and I know he'll never stay still for the doctor. He hates anyone touching his face even on a good day.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's very common for toddlers his age. Let me check his vital signs real quick. Can you hold him on your lap? Tommy, I'm just going to listen to your heart.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Come here, sweetie. The nurse is going to help make your lip better. Is he going to need stitches?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Based on what I can see, this will likely need to be sutured by the doctor. His vital signs look good - heart rate, blood pressure, and breathing are all normal for his age.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Will they be able to do it with him awake? I'm really worried about him being scared and not cooperating.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Given his age and the location of the cut, the doctor will probably recommend some sedation to help him stay calm and still. This ensures the best cosmetic outcome since it's on his face.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Okay, I understand. Is he otherwise healthy - no medical problems or allergies that I should mention?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: No, he's a healthy little guy. No allergies that we know of, and he's up to date on all his shots.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Perfect. Let me get you both back to a room so the doctor can take a closer look and discuss the treatment plan with you.

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. A 44-year-old diabetic with continuous vomiting is at risk for diabetic ketoacidosis. The patient's vital signs are a concern, as her heart rate and respiratory rate are both elevated. It is not safe for this patient to wait for an extended period of time in the waiting room.

meta.source_case_text: A 44-year-old female is retching continuously into a large basin as her son wheels her into the triage area. Her son tells you that his diabetic mother has been vomiting for the past 5 hours, and now it is "just this yellow stuff." "She hasn't eaten or taken her insulin," he tells you. No known drug allergies. Vital signs: BP 148/70, P 126, RR 24.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. A 44-year-old diabetic with continuous vomiting is at risk for diabetic ketoacidosis. The patient's vital signs are a concern, as her heart rate and respiratory rate are both elevated. It is not safe for this patient to wait for an extended period of time in the waiting room.

conversation.speaker: son
conversation.message: Nurse! Please help! My mom has been throwing up for hours and she can't stop!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. Let me help you get her settled. I can see she's actively retching. How long has this been going on?

conversation.speaker: son
conversation.message: She's been vomiting for the past 5 hours straight. Now it's just this yellow stuff coming up. She's diabetic and she hasn't eaten anything or taken her insulin today because she keeps throwing up.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: *retching into basin* *weak voice* I... I feel so sick... can't... can't stop...

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Ma'am, I know you're feeling terrible right now. I'm going to take your vital signs and get you seen immediately. Do you have any drug allergies?

conversation.speaker: son
conversation.message: No, she doesn't have any known drug allergies. But she's diabetic - she takes insulin every day. I'm really worried about her blood sugar.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: *retching continues* *weakly* Everything... everything is spinning... feel awful...

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your blood pressure is 148 over 70, your heart rate is elevated at 126, and your breathing rate is 24. Given that you're diabetic, haven't taken insulin, and have been vomiting continuously, I'm very concerned about diabetic ketoacidosis.

conversation.speaker: son
conversation.message: Diabetic ketoacidosis? Is that serious? Should I have brought her in sooner?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You did exactly the right thing bringing her in now. DKA can be very serious, but it's treatable. I'm going to get her into a treatment room immediately - this is a high priority case and she needs to be seen right away.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: *continues retching* *barely audible* Thank you... need help...

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We're going to take excellent care of you. I'm calling for a wheelchair and we'll get you back to a room where the doctor can start treatment immediately.

expected.esi_rationale: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. This 76-year-old patient is in hemorrhagic shock from his GI bleed. His blood pressure is 70, his heart rate is 128, and his respiratory rate is 40, all indicating an attempt to compensate for his blood loss. This patient needs immediate IV access and the administration of fluid, blood, and medications.

meta.source_case_text: EMS arrives with a 76-year-old male found on the bathroom floor. The family called 911 when they heard a loud crash in the bathroom. The patient was found in his underwear, and the toilet bowl was filled with maroon-colored stool. Vital signs on arrival: BP 70/palp, HR 128, RR 40. His family tells you he has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes a "little blue pill to thin his blood."
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 1: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. This 76-year-old patient is in hemorrhagic shock from his GI bleed. His blood pressure is 70, his heart rate is 128, and his respiratory rate is 40, all indicating an attempt to compensate for his blood loss. This patient needs immediate IV access and the administration of fluid, blood, and medications.

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Incoming trauma alert! We've got a 76-year-old male found down on his bathroom floor. Family called 911 after hearing a loud crash.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Go ahead with your report. What's his current status?

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Patient was found in his underwear, and there was maroon-colored stool filling the toilet bowl. He's conscious but very weak. Vitals are critical - blood pressure 70 palpable only, heart rate 128, respiratory rate 40. We've got him on high-flow oxygen.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Jesus, those are shock vitals. Any IV access?

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: We got one 18-gauge in his left arm, running wide open with normal saline. He's been getting increasingly pale and diaphoretic during transport.

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: Is he going to be okay? We just heard this terrible crash from upstairs and found him collapsed on the bathroom floor!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We're going to take excellent care of him. Can you tell me about his medical history? Any medications he takes?

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: He has that heart rhythm problem - atrial fibrillation, I think the doctor called it. He takes a little blue pill every day to thin his blood.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The blood thinner - that's likely warfarin or Coumadin. That explains the severity of his bleeding. How long ago did you find him?

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: Maybe 20 minutes ago? He was supposed to come down for dinner and when we heard that crash, we ran upstairs. There was so much blood in the toilet...

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Patient's getting weaker. His pressure's dropping even more - I can barely feel a pulse now.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: This is a Level 1 trauma activation. Get him straight to Resuscitation Bay 1 immediately. I'm calling for the trauma team, blood bank, and OR to be notified now. This man is in hemorrhagic shock from a massive GI bleed.

conversation.speaker: family_member
conversation.message: Hemorrhagic shock? What does that mean?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: It means he's lost a dangerous amount of blood very quickly. His blood pressure is critically low and his heart is racing to try to compensate. We need to get him blood products and stop the bleeding immediately.

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Should we take him straight to the trauma bay?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Absolutely. No triage, no waiting. This patient needs immediate lifesaving intervention. Let's move!

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. From the patient's history, he will require labs and IV fluid replacement—two resources.

meta.source_case_text: I think I picked up a bug overseas," reports a 34-year-old male who presented in the emergency department complaining of frequent watery stools and abdominal cramping. "I think I am getting dehydrated." T 98°F, RR 22, HR 112, BP 120/80, SpO2 100%. His lips are dry and cracked.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. From the patient's history, he will require labs and IV fluid replacement—two resources.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I think I picked up a bug overseas. I just got back from a trip to Southeast Asia last week.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see. What symptoms are you experiencing that brought you in today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I've been having frequent watery stools for the past few days, and I'm getting pretty bad abdominal cramping. It's been getting worse.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: How often are you having bowel movements, and when did this start?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It started about three days ago, maybe the day after I got back. I'm going to the bathroom probably every couple of hours with very watery diarrhea.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That sounds uncomfortable. Are you experiencing any other symptoms like nausea, vomiting, or fever?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I think I am getting dehydrated. I've been trying to drink fluids, but I feel pretty weak and lightheaded when I stand up.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, let me get your vital signs and take a look at you. Can you confirm your age for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 34 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Alright, I'm getting your vitals now. Your temperature is 98 degrees Fahrenheit, which is normal. Your heart rate is a bit elevated at 112, respiratory rate is 22, blood pressure is 120 over 80, and your oxygen saturation is 100 percent.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see that your lips appear dry and cracked, which can be a sign of dehydration along with your elevated heart rate.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, I've been trying to stay hydrated, but it's hard when everything just goes right through me. Should I be worried about this?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Traveler's diarrhea is common after overseas trips, especially to certain regions. Given your symptoms and signs of dehydration, we'll need to evaluate you more thoroughly. The doctor will likely want to run some laboratory tests and may need to give you IV fluids to help with the dehydration.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That makes sense. How long do you think this will take to resolve?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That will depend on what the tests show and how you respond to treatment. Let me get you registered and into a room so we can get you more comfortable and start your evaluation.

meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. It looks as though this patient has a displaced fracture and will need a closed reduction prior to casting or splinting. However, there are already two or more resources, so it is not necessary to be overly concerned about counting resources beyond two.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Patricia, the triage nurse. What brings you and your son to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Hi, I think he broke it. My son was climbing a tree in our backyard and fell about 5 feet, landing right on his arm.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Oh my, that sounds scary. What's your son's name and how old is he?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: This is Jake, he's 9 years old. I'm actually a nurse myself, so I put on a splint and applied ice right away when I saw how his arm looked.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That was smart thinking. I can see the splint you applied. Jake, can you tell me how you're feeling right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It hurts, but not too bad. Mom gave me some medicine at home. I'm sorry I climbed so high in the tree.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You don't need to apologize, honey. Kids climb trees - it's what kids do. Can you wiggle your fingers for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, I can move them. See? It just hurts when I try to move my arm.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: I checked his pulse right after it happened and it was good. I can see the arm is obviously deformed though - you can tell it's not straight.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good job checking that. Let me get his vital signs. Jake, on a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain you've ever felt, how much does your arm hurt right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Um, maybe like a 5? It was worse right when I fell, but the ice helped.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, that's helpful. His temperature is 98 degrees, heart rate is 90, respiratory rate is 26, and oxygen saturation is 99%. All pretty normal for a child his age who's been through some stress.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: So what's the next step? I assume he'll need X-rays to confirm it's broken and see exactly what kind of fracture it is?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Yes, exactly. Based on what I can see and your description of the fall, we'll definitely need X-rays. The doctor will also likely want to consult with orthopedics about the best way to treat this type of fracture.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Will I need surgery? My friend had surgery when he broke his arm playing baseball.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's a great question for the doctor after we get your X-rays, Jake. Some fractures need surgery and some don't - it depends on exactly how the bone is broken. Let's get you back to a room so we can take some pictures of your arm.

meta.source_case_text: "I don't know what's wrong with my baby girl," cries a young mother. She reports that her 2-week-old baby is not acting right and is not interested in eating. As you begin to undress the baby, you notice that she is listless and her skin is mottled.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 1: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention; possible aggressive fluid resuscitation.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Please help me! I don't know what's wrong with my baby girl! She's not acting right at all!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm here to help you. Let me see your baby. How old is she?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: She's only 2 weeks old. She was born healthy, but since yesterday she's just not been herself. She won't eat and she's so sleepy.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: When did you first notice she wasn't acting normally?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Yesterday she started refusing her bottles. She usually eats every 2-3 hours, but she barely took anything yesterday and nothing at all today. I tried waking her to feed her, but she just won't wake up properly.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I need to examine her right away. Let me help you undress her so I can get a full assessment.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: She feels different when I hold her. Not as responsive as usual. Is that normal?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see that she's very listless and I'm noticing that her skin has a mottled appearance. This is very concerning in a baby this young. We need to get her back to a trauma room immediately.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Mottled? What does that mean? Is she going to be okay?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: It means her circulation isn't optimal. In a 2-week-old baby, this combination of symptoms - not feeding, lethargy, and mottled skin - requires immediate medical attention. I'm calling for the pediatric team right now.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Oh God, is this serious? I should have brought her in sooner!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You did exactly the right thing bringing her in. We're going to take excellent care of her. The medical team is on their way and we're moving her to our critical care area immediately. This is our top priority right now.

expected.esi_rationale: Severe pain or distress. This patient needs aggressive pain management with IV medications. There is nothing the triage nurse can do to decrease the patient's pain level. The answer to "Would you give your last open bed to this patient?" should be yes.

meta.source_case_text: "My pain medications are not working anymore. Last night I couldn't sleep because the pain was so bad," reports a 47-year-old female with metastatic ovarian cancer. "My husband called my oncologist, and he told me to come to the emergency department." The patient rates her pain as 9/10. Vital signs are within normal limits.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: Severe pain or distress. This patient needs aggressive pain management with IV medications. There is nothing the triage nurse can do to decrease the patient's pain level. The answer to "Would you give your last open bed to this patient?" should be yes.

conversation.speaker: Patient
conversation.message: Excuse me, nurse, I need help. My pain medications are not working anymore.

conversation.speaker: Triage Nurse
conversation.message: I'm here to help you. Can you tell me your name and date of birth first?

conversation.speaker: Patient
conversation.message: Sarah Mitchell, March 15th, 1977. Listen, last night I couldn't sleep because the pain was so bad. I've been dealing with ovarian cancer, metastatic, and my usual pain meds just aren't cutting it anymore.

conversation.speaker: Triage Nurse
conversation.message: I'm sorry you're experiencing such severe pain, Sarah. On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate your pain right now?

conversation.speaker: Patient
conversation.message: It's a 9 out of 10. I can barely concentrate. My husband called my oncologist this morning because I was in tears.

conversation.speaker: Husband
conversation.message: Dr. Patel told us to come to the emergency department immediately. He said Sarah needs stronger pain management than what we can do at home.

conversation.speaker: Triage Nurse
conversation.message: I understand. Let me get your vital signs and we'll get you back to be seen right away. Can you tell me what pain medications you've been taking at home?

conversation.speaker: Patient
conversation.message: I'm on OxyContin extended release twice a day, and oxycodone for breakthrough pain. But even taking the breakthrough doses every few hours isn't helping anymore.

conversation.speaker: Triage Nurse
conversation.message: Okay, let me check your blood pressure, heart rate, and temperature. Your vital signs look stable - blood pressure is good, heart rate normal, no fever. Have you had any nausea or vomiting with the increased pain?

conversation.speaker: Patient

conversation.speaker: Triage Nurse
conversation.message: I completely understand, and we're going to take excellent care of you. Cancer pain that breaks through your regular medications needs immediate attention. I'm going to get you back to a room right now so the doctor can evaluate you and get you some IV pain medication.

conversation.speaker: Husband
conversation.message: How long will it take? She's been suffering for hours.

conversation.speaker: Triage Nurse
conversation.message: Pain control is one of our top priorities. I'm classifying this as urgent, which means she'll be seen very quickly. The doctor will likely start with IV pain medication while we figure out the best long-term plan with her oncologist.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses here. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient

conversation.speaker: nurse

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's that familiar pain on my right side, right here in my back area, and it radiates around to the front and down into my groin. It's exactly like my previous kidney stones.

conversation.speaker: nurse

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm feeling nauseous, yes, but I haven't actually thrown up. I took one of my pain pills from last time about an hour ago, so the pain isn't too bad right now.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That was smart thinking ahead. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain you can imagine, how would you rate your current pain level?

conversation.speaker: patient

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 48 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That makes sense. Will I need another CT scan like last time?

conversation.speaker: nurse

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. Rashes are difficult to triage, but the presence of petechiae is always a high-risk situation. Even if the patient looks good, it is important to recognize that petechia can be a symptom of a life-threatening infection, meningococcemia.

meta.source_case_text: "After my pediatrician saw my son's rash, he said I had to bring him to the emergency department immediately. He has this rash on his face and chest that started today. He has little pinpoint purplish spots he called petechiae. My son is a healthy kid who has had a cold for a couple of days and a cough. My pediatrician said he had to be sure nothing bad is going on. What do you think?"
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. Rashes are difficult to triage, but the presence of petechiae is always a high-risk situation. Even if the patient looks good, it is important to recognize that petechia can be a symptom of a life-threatening infection, meningococcemia.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Hi, we're here because our pediatrician Dr. Martinez told us to come to the emergency department right away after seeing my son's rash. He said it was urgent and we needed to come immediately.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm glad you came in. I'm Sarah, one of the triage nurses here. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with your son and what the pediatrician was concerned about?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Well, my son started getting this rash on his face and chest just today. Dr. Martinez called them petechiae - little pinpoint purplish spots. He got really serious when he saw them and said we had to come here to make sure nothing bad is going on.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern. Has your son been feeling unwell recently, or have you noticed any other symptoms?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: He's had a cold for a couple of days now - you know, runny nose and a cough. But he's normally such a healthy kid, never really gets sick. The rash just appeared this morning, which is why I took him to Dr. Martinez.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: How is your son feeling right now? Is he acting like his normal self, or have you noticed any changes in his behavior or energy level?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: He seems pretty much like himself - maybe a little tired from the cold, but he's been playing and eating normally. That's what's so confusing to me. Dr. Martinez seemed really worried, but my son doesn't seem that sick.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Dr. Martinez was right to send you here. Those types of spots can sometimes indicate a serious infection that needs immediate attention, even when children seem relatively well. We're going to need to get your son seen by our doctors very quickly to rule out anything serious.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Oh my goodness, that sounds terrifying. What kind of serious infection? Should I be worried?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I know this is scary, but you did exactly the right thing by bringing him in when your pediatrician recommended it. The doctors will want to examine him thoroughly and may need to run some tests to make sure everything is okay. We're going to get him seen right away.

meta.source_case_text: "Her grandfather pulled her by the wrist up and over a big puddle. Next thing you know, she is crying and refusing to move her left arm," the mother of a healthy 3–year-old tells you. Vital signs are within normal limits.

conversation.speaker: mother

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Of course, let me get some information. What's your daughter's name and how old is she?

conversation.message: Her name is Emma and she's 3 years old. She's normally very active and healthy, no medical problems.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Can you tell me what happened to her arm?

conversation.speaker: mother

conversation.speaker: nurse

conversation.speaker: mother

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Any fever, or is she acting sick in any other way besides the arm pain?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: No fever, she feels normal temperature-wise. She's just upset about her arm and wants me to hold her. Otherwise she seems like herself.

conversation.speaker: nurse

conversation.speaker: triage_nurse
