conversation.message: Copy that. Trauma bay 1 is ready. What's his current status?

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Patient is conscious but in severe respiratory distress. He's moaning and saying he can't breathe. There's a large hematoma forming around the wound site on the left neck. Vitals are concerning - heart rate 110, respiratory rate 36, oxygen saturation 89% on high-flow oxygen.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: *moaning* I can't... can't breathe... help me...

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Sir, I'm the triage nurse. We're going to take excellent care of you. Can you tell me your name?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: *struggling to speak* Mike... Mike Johnson... please... I can't... *gasping*

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Incident occurred approximately 20 minutes ago. Bystanders called 911 immediately. Patient was found conscious at scene with active bleeding from neck wound. We've maintained cervical spine precautions and applied direct pressure to control bleeding.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Mike, I can see you're having trouble breathing. The hematoma around your neck wound is quite large and may be putting pressure on your airway. We need to get you to the trauma room immediately.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: *barely audible* It's getting... harder... to breathe...

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Dr. Martinez, we need you in trauma 1 immediately! 28-year-old male with penetrating neck trauma, large expanding hematoma, and compromising airway. Patient is in respiratory distress with oxygen saturation 89%.

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: We've maintained IV access and given normal saline. No other apparent injuries noted during our assessment. The wound appears to be approximately 3 centimeters in length on the left lateral neck.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Mike, we're moving you to our trauma room right now. You're our absolute highest priority. We may need to help you breathe with a breathing tube to keep you safe while we evaluate and treat your injury.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: *weakening voice* Am I... going to... be okay?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We have an excellent trauma team here and we're going to do everything possible to take care of you. Right now our biggest concern is making sure you can breathe properly, and then we'll take care of your neck wound.

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Patient has no known allergies and no significant medical history according to the information we gathered at scene. No other medications noted.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Let's move! This is a potential surgical airway situation. Get anesthesia and surgery down here stat. We need to be prepared for emergency intubation or cricothyrotomy if this hematoma continues to expand.

expected.esi_rationale: No resources. This healthy-sounding 11-year-old will be examined by a physician and then discharged home with appropriate instructions and a prescription if indicated.

meta.source_case_text: An 11-year-old presents to triage with his mother, who reports that her son has had a cough and runny nose for a week. The child is running around the waiting room and asking his mother for a snack. Vital signs are within normal limits.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 5: No resources. This healthy-sounding 11-year-old will be examined by a physician and then discharged home with appropriate instructions and a prescription if indicated.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon! I'm Sarah, the triage nurse. What brings you and your son to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Hi, my son has had a cough and runny nose for about a week now. I wasn't sure if I should bring him in, but it's not getting better.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern. And what's your son's name and age?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: This is Michael, and he's 11 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi Michael! How are you feeling today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm okay, just have this annoying cough. Mom, can I get something from the vending machine? I'm hungry.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: See what I mean? He's been like this all week - still his usual energetic self, just with this persistent cold symptoms.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's actually a good sign that he's feeling well enough to ask for snacks! Michael, can you tell me about your cough? Is it bringing up any mucus or is it dry?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It's just annoying. Sometimes there's a little bit of clear stuff, but mostly it just makes me cough a lot, especially at night.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: And how about your nose? Stuffy or runny?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Runny mostly. I've gone through like a whole box of tissues this week!

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: He's been sleeping okay, eating normally, playing with his friends. No fever that I've noticed. I just got worried because it's been going on for a week and doesn't seem to be improving.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You're being a good mom by bringing him in. Let me check his vital signs. Michael, can you stand on the scale for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Sure! Mom, after this can we get pizza for dinner?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: We'll see, sweetie. As you can tell, his appetite is definitely not affected!

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's wonderful to hear! Let me get his temperature, blood pressure, and heart rate.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Michael's vital signs are all completely normal - temperature, heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen levels are all within the normal range for his age.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: That's reassuring. So you think it's just a cold?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Based on what I'm seeing - a week of cold symptoms in an otherwise healthy, active child with normal vital signs - it does appear to be a simple upper respiratory infection. The doctor will examine him to confirm, but this looks like something that can be managed with rest and supportive care.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Does that mean I don't have to get a shot?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Most likely no shots needed today, Michael! The doctor will take a listen to your lungs and check your throat, but this seems like a straightforward cold that just needs time to get better.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: How long should we expect this to last?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Typically, cold symptoms can last 7-10 days. Since it's been a week, he's probably starting to turn the corner. The doctor will give you specific guidance on when to follow up if symptoms worsen or don't improve.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Can I go back to soccer practice this week?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's a great question for the doctor! You can have a seat in the waiting room and we'll call you back shortly. This shouldn't be a long wait since Michael is stable and doing well.

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. This patient has an elevated respiratory rate and heart rate. The symptoms of polydipsia and polyuria are two classic signs of diabetic ketoacisosis.

meta.source_case_text: "I don't know what is wrong with my son," reports the worried mother of a normally healthy eight-year-old male. "He's losing weight and acting so cranky. Last night he was up to the bathroom every hour, and he can't seem to get enough to drink." The child is alert and oriented and answers your questions appropriately. Vital signs: T 98.6°F, RR 30, HR 98, BP 92/78, SpO2 98%.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. This patient has an elevated respiratory rate and heart rate. The symptoms of polydipsia and polyuria are two classic signs of diabetic ketoacisosis.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. What brings you and your son to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Hi, I don't know what is wrong with my son. Something's just not right with him. He's normally such a healthy eight-year-old, but lately he's been acting so different.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you're worried about him. Can you tell me more about what changes you've noticed?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Well, he's been losing weight even though he seems to be eating normally. And he's been so cranky and irritable, which is really not like him at all. Last night was the worst - he was up to the bathroom every hour.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That must have been exhausting for both of you. You mentioned he was going to the bathroom frequently - was he urinating each time?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Yes, and he can't seem to get enough to drink. He's been asking for water constantly, which is unusual for him. I keep filling up his water bottle over and over again.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern. Hi there, what's your name, sweetheart?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm Michael. I feel okay right now, but I'm really thirsty. Can I have some water?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Of course, Michael. You can have some water in just a moment. Can you tell me how you've been feeling lately?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I've been really tired and I have to go to the bathroom a lot. And I'm always thirsty, even after I drink water.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you for telling me that, Michael. Mom, has he had any fever or seemed sick in any other way?

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: No fever that I've noticed, but he just seems so different. More tired than usual, and definitely more irritable. Should I be worried?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Let me get his vital signs first. Michael, I'm going to check your temperature and blood pressure, okay? This won't hurt at all.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay. Will this take long? I really need to use the bathroom again.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We'll be quick, I promise. His temperature is 98.6 degrees, which is normal. His heart rate is 98, respiratory rate is 30, blood pressure is 92 over 78, and oxygen saturation is 98%.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Are those numbers okay? Is his breathing faster than normal?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: His breathing rate is a bit elevated for his age, and his heart rate is also on the higher side. Combined with the symptoms you've described - the excessive urination, increased thirst, and weight loss - we need to have the doctor see him right away.

conversation.speaker: mother
conversation.message: Right away? That sounds serious. What do you think might be wrong?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The combination of symptoms you've described can be signs of a condition that needs prompt medical attention. The doctor will want to run some tests to determine exactly what's going on. We're going to prioritize getting Michael seen quickly.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Mom, I really need to go to the bathroom now. And I'm still really thirsty.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Of course, sweetheart. The bathroom is right down the hall. Mom, I'm going to get you both into a room immediately. This is a priority case that needs urgent evaluation.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. This 19-month-old is dehydrated and will require a minimum of two resources: labs and IV fluids. In addition the physician may order an IV antiemetic.

meta.source_case_text: "He has had diarrhea for 2 days, and he just started throwing up this morning. This has been going around the family, and he seems to have it the worst. He has been drinking before today, but now he doesn't want anything to drink," reports the mother of a 19-month-old. The toddler is awake and alert but quiet in the mother's arms, and you notice his lips are dry and cracked. Vital signs: T 99°F, RR 30, HR 130, SpO2 100%.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. This 19-month-old is dehydrated and will require a minimum of two resources: labs and IV fluids. In addition the physician may order an IV antiemetic.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good morning, I'm Sarah, the triage nurse. What brings you and your little one to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: He has had diarrhea for 2 days, and he just started throwing up this morning. This has been going around the family, and he seems to have it the worst.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm sorry to hear that. How is his fluid intake been? Has he been able to keep anything down?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: He has been drinking before today, but now he doesn't want anything to drink. Every time I try to give him his sippy cup, he just pushes it away.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern. Let me take his vital signs and examine him. What's his name?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: This is Tommy. He's usually such an active little guy, but today he's just been so quiet and clingy.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi Tommy. I can see he's awake and alert, which is good, but he does seem unusually quiet for a 19-month-old. I'm noticing his lips look dry and cracked.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, I noticed that too. And his diaper hasn't been very wet either. I'm really worried about dehydration.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your concerns are very valid. His vital signs show a temperature of 99 degrees, respiratory rate of 30, heart rate of 130, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The elevated heart rate is concerning for dehydration.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Is that heart rate too high? What does that mean for Tommy?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: For a 19-month-old, the normal resting heart rate is typically between 80-130, so 130 is at the upper limit and suggests his body is working harder, likely due to fluid loss from the diarrhea and vomiting.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: So he really is dehydrated then? What are you going to do to help him?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Based on his symptoms and physical exam, Tommy will need IV fluids to help rehydrate him. The doctor will also want to run some blood work to check his electrolyte levels and kidney function.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: IV fluids? That means a needle, right? He's going to be so scared. Is there any other way?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I know it's difficult, but given his level of dehydration and the fact that he's refusing oral fluids, IV rehydration is the safest and most effective treatment. We'll do everything we can to make him comfortable.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, if that's what he needs. How long will this take? And will he need to stay in the hospital?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That will depend on how he responds to the IV fluids and what his lab results show. Many children with gastroenteritis can be rehydrated and go home the same day, but we'll monitor him closely.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Thank you for explaining everything. I just want him to feel better.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Of course. I'm going to get you both into a room right away so we can start his treatment. This is a priority case that needs prompt attention.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. This patient probably has a fractured hip and will need an x ray, IV pain medication, and an orthopedic consult. If the reason for a fall in the elderly is unclear, the patient should be assigned ESI level 2 to rule out a cardiac or neurological event.

meta.source_case_text: EMS arrives with an 87-year-old male who slipped on the ice and injured his right hip. His right leg is shortened and externally rotated. The patient's only complaint is hip pain. He rates his pain as 5/10, and his vital signs are within normal limits.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. This patient probably has a fractured hip and will need an x ray, IV pain medication, and an orthopedic consult. If the reason for a fall in the elderly is unclear, the patient should be assigned ESI level 2 to rule out a cardiac or neurological event.

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: Triage, we're bringing in an 87-year-old male who fell on the ice outside his house about an hour ago. He's injured his right hip.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Copy that. What's his current condition and mechanism of injury?

conversation.speaker: ems_paramedic
conversation.message: He slipped on the ice on his front walkway and went down hard on his right side. His right leg is visibly shortened and externally rotated. Vitals are stable - BP 142/78, heart rate 82, respirations 18, oxygen sat 97% on room air.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, let's get him into room 3. Sir, I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. Can you tell me your name and date of birth?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Robert Thompson, March 15th, 1937. This hip is really hurting me, nurse.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you're in pain, Mr. Thompson. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain you've ever felt, how would you rate your hip pain right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'd say about a 5. It's not terrible, but it definitely hurts, especially when I try to move.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's helpful to know. Can you tell me exactly what happened when you fell? Did you feel dizzy or faint before you slipped?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, nothing like that. I was just walking out to get my mail like I do every morning. The ice was pretty thick on the walkway and my foot just went right out from under me. I came down hard on my right side.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Did you hit your head when you fell? Any loss of consciousness?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I didn't hit my head. I was awake the whole time. Just this darn hip that's giving me trouble now.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Are you having any pain anywhere else? Any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, just the hip. Everything else feels fine. I just can't put any weight on this leg at all.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand. What medications do you normally take, Mr. Thompson?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Just my blood pressure medication - lisinopril - and a baby aspirin every day. That's it.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Any allergies to medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No allergies that I know of.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, Mr. Thompson. Based on your injury and symptoms, we're going to need to get an X-ray of your hip to see what's going on with the bone. The doctor will also want to start you on some IV pain medication to help make you more comfortable, and we'll likely need to have an orthopedic specialist take a look at you.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Do you think it's broken? I was afraid of that when I couldn't stand up.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: The way your leg is positioned and the mechanism of your fall are certainly concerning for a possible fracture, but we'll need those X-rays to know for sure. The good news is that your vital signs are stable and you're alert and oriented. We're going to take excellent care of you.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Thank you, nurse. I appreciate that. How long do you think this will take?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We'll get you back to a room shortly and start working on getting you more comfortable. The X-rays shouldn't take too long, and then we'll have a much better idea of what we're dealing with and what the next steps will be.

expected.esi_rationale: No resources. Following a physical exam, this baby will be discharged to home. Prior to leaving, the mother needs to be taught techniques to keep the baby's nares clear of mucus.

meta.source_case_text: "My baby is having a hard time drinking his bottle," reports the young mother of a 3–month-old. The baby is alert and looking around. You notice a large amount of dried mucus around both nares. T 98°F, RR 40, HR 132, SpO2 99%.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 5: No resources. Following a physical exam, this baby will be discharged to home. Prior to leaving, the mother needs to be taught techniques to keep the baby's nares clear of mucus.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good morning, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you and your little one in today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I'm worried about my baby. He's having a hard time drinking his bottle. He keeps pulling away and seems frustrated when he tries to eat.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can understand your concern. How old is your baby, and when did you first notice this problem?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: He's 3 months old, and it started yesterday. At first I thought maybe he wasn't hungry, but even when I know he should be hungry, he struggles with the bottle.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I see. Let me take a look at him. I notice there's quite a bit of dried mucus around his nose. Has he had any cold symptoms or congestion?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Well, yes, his nose has been a bit stuffy. I've seen the dried mucus but I wasn't sure if that was related to his feeding problem.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: It very well could be. Babies breathe primarily through their noses, so when they're congested, it can make feeding difficult. Let me check his vital signs. How has he been otherwise - alert, active?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Oh yes, he's been very alert and looking around like he always does. He doesn't seem sick otherwise, just frustrated when eating.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good to hear. His vital signs look normal - temperature is 98 degrees, and his breathing and heart rate are appropriate for his age. Has he had any fever, vomiting, or changes in his bowel movements?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No fever, no vomiting, and his diapers have been normal. He just seems to have trouble with feeding because of his stuffy nose.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Based on what you're describing and what I'm observing, it sounds like nasal congestion is likely interfering with his ability to feed comfortably. The doctor will examine him, but this appears to be a common issue we see with congested babies.

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. An elderly patient with increasing confusion and a fever needs to be evaluated for an infection. UTIs and pneumonia need to be ruled out. This patient may be septic and requires rapid evaluation and treatment.

meta.source_case_text: A 72-year-old female is brought in by ambulance from the nearby nursing home. They report that she has become increasingly confused over the last 24 hours. She is usually awake, alert, and oriented and takes care of her own activities of daily living. At triage she has a temperature of 99.6°F, HR 86, RR 28, BP 136/72, SpO2 94% on room air.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. An elderly patient with increasing confusion and a fever needs to be evaluated for an infection. UTIs and pneumonia need to be ruled out. This patient may be septic and requires rapid evaluation and treatment.

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: We're bringing in a 72-year-old female from Sunset Manor nursing home. Staff reports she's been increasingly confused over the past 24 hours, which is very unusual for her. She's normally alert and oriented, manages her own daily activities.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. What's her baseline mental status like according to the nursing home?

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: They say she's usually sharp as a tack - awake, alert, oriented times three. Takes care of herself completely. This confusion started yesterday and has been getting worse.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, let's get her vitals. Mrs. Johnson, can you tell me your name?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I... where am I? Who are these people? I want to go home.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You're at the hospital, Mrs. Johnson. We're here to help you feel better. Let me check your temperature - it's 99.6 degrees. Your heart rate is 86, blood pressure 136 over 72.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your breathing is a little fast at 28 breaths per minute, and your oxygen level is 94 percent. Mrs. Johnson, do you have any pain anywhere?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I don't know... I'm confused. Why can't I think clearly? This isn't like me.

conversation.speaker: nursing_home_aide
conversation.message: Nurse, this really isn't like her at all. Yesterday morning she was helping other residents and playing cards. By evening she was asking the same questions over and over.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you for that information. With her change in mental status and low-grade fever, we need to rule out infection quickly.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.message: What are we looking at here?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: 72-year-old from nursing home with acute onset confusion over 24 hours. Baseline is alert and independent. Low-grade fever, slightly tachypneic, O2 sat 94 percent on room air.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.message: Classic presentation for sepsis in elderly. Let's get blood cultures, CBC, comprehensive metabolic panel, urinalysis, and chest X-ray. Start an IV and get lactate level. We need to move quickly on this one.

expected.esi_rationale: New-onset confusion, lethargy, or disorientation. The mother of this 4-year-old knows her child and has probably been through this situation before. A child with a ventriculo-peritoneal shunt with a change in level of consciousness and a headache is thought to have a blocked shunt until proven otherwise and may be experiencing increased intracranial pressure.

meta.source_case_text: Melissa, a 4-year-old with a ventriculo-peritoneal shunt (drains excess cerebrospinal fluid), is brought to the ED by her parents. The mother tells you that she is concerned that the shunt may be blocked because Melissa is not acting right. The child is sleepy but responds to verbal stimuli. When asked what was wrong, she tells you that her head hurts and she is going to throw up. T 98.6°F, RR 22, HR 120, SpO2 99% on room air, BP 94/76.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: New-onset confusion, lethargy, or disorientation. The mother of this 4-year-old knows her child and has probably been through this situation before. A child with a ventriculo-peritoneal shunt with a change in level of consciousness and a headache is thought to have a blocked shunt until proven otherwise and may be experiencing increased intracranial pressure.

conversation.speaker: parent
conversation.message: Hi, we're here with our daughter Melissa. She's four years old and has a ventriculo-peritoneal shunt. I'm really worried because she's not acting right today.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you're concerned. Tell me more about what you've noticed that's different about Melissa today.

conversation.speaker: parent
conversation.message: Well, she's been really sleepy all day, much more than usual. And she's just not herself - usually she's running around and talking constantly, but today she's just been lying around. I'm worried her shunt might be blocked.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Has she had any symptoms like headache, nausea, or vomiting? And has this happened before with her shunt?

conversation.speaker: parent
conversation.message: Yes, we've been through this once before when her shunt got blocked. That's why I'm so worried. She keeps saying her head hurts, and a little while ago she told me she felt like she was going to throw up.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Melissa, sweetie, can you tell me how you're feeling right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: My head hurts... and I feel sick. I wanna go home.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand, honey. We're going to help you feel better. Let me check your vital signs and get you seen by the doctor right away. Has she been eating and drinking normally today?

conversation.speaker: parent
conversation.message: Not really. She didn't want breakfast this morning, and she's only had a few sips of water. She just seems so lethargic. With her shunt history, I know this could be serious.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You absolutely did the right thing bringing her in. Let me get her vital signs - temperature is 98.6, heart rate is 120, respiratory rate 22, blood pressure 94 over 76, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. I'm going to get the doctor immediately and we'll get her back to a room right away.

conversation.speaker: parent
conversation.message: Thank you. Is her heart rate high? She usually runs around so much more than this.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Her heart rate is a bit elevated for her age, and combined with her symptoms and shunt history, we definitely want to evaluate her urgently for any signs of increased pressure. The doctor will likely want to get some imaging to check the shunt function.

expected.esi_rationale: Requires immediate lifesaving intervention. This patient is experiencing another cardiac event that requires immediate treatment. His vital signs and skin perfusion are suggestive of cardiogenic shock, and the patient may require fluid resuscitation or vasopressors to treat hypotension.

conversation.message: Code STEMI, Code STEMI. EMS arrival to emergency department. Code STEMI, Code STEMI.

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: We have a 62-year-old male with chest pressure that started about an hour ago. Patient has a history of MI four years ago. Field EKG shows anterior lateral ischemic changes.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Copy that. Trauma bay 1 is ready. What are his current vitals?

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Heart rate 106, respiratory rate 28, blood pressure is critically low at 72 over 53. SpO2 is 95% on a non-rebreather mask. His skin is cool and clammy to touch.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Those vitals are concerning for cardiogenic shock. Let's get him into the bay immediately. Doctor, we need you here now!

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: The pressure... it's just like before... when I had my heart attack. It's crushing my chest.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.message: This patient needs immediate intervention. Get a 12-lead EKG, large bore IV access, and prepare for possible emergency catheterization. We need to get cardiology down here stat.

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Patient has been complaining of chest pressure for the past hour. No relief with rest. He recognized the symptoms from his previous MI four years ago and called 911 immediately.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Sir, we're going to take excellent care of you. Can you tell me about any medications you're currently taking?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm on... on my blood thinners... and my heart pills... but this pain... it's just like last time.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.message: Based on his presentation and field EKG findings, this is a STEMI with signs of cardiogenic shock. We need to move fast - get the cath lab team activated immediately.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of an infection. At a minimum, he will require labs, an x ray, an orthopedic consult, and IV antibiotics.

meta.source_case_text: "I had a knee replacement 3 months ago. Now look at it!" states a 64-year-old male. The knee is red, swollen and tender to touch. Vital signs: T 99°F, RR 20, HR 74, BP 164/74, SpO2 97%. Pain 6/10.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of an infection. At a minimum, he will require labs, an x ray, an orthopedic consult, and IV antibiotics.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Maria, one of the triage nurses here. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I had a knee replacement 3 months ago. Now look at it! Something's definitely not right with my knee.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you're concerned about your knee. Can you tell me what specific changes you've noticed since your surgery?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Well, it's gotten really red and swollen over the past few days. It's much more swollen than it was during my normal recovery.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand. Is the knee painful when I gently touch around this area?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, it's definitely tender to touch. That hurts when you press there.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm sorry, I'll be more gentle. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain imaginable, how would you rate your current knee pain?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'd say it's about a 6 out of 10. It's not excruciating, but it's definitely uncomfortable and concerning.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Have you noticed any fever or chills recently?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: You know, I have felt a little warm today, but I wasn't sure if that was related or not.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Let me get your vital signs and temperature. Can you confirm your age for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 64 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. Your temperature is 99 degrees Fahrenheit, which is slightly elevated. Your heart rate is 74, respiratory rate is 20, blood pressure is 164 over 74, and your oxygen saturation is 97 percent on room air.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Is that temperature high enough to be concerning? I'm worried this might be an infection around my knee replacement.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your symptoms - the redness, swelling, tenderness, and low-grade fever - are definitely concerning for a possible infection, especially given your recent knee replacement surgery. The doctor will need to evaluate this thoroughly. We'll likely need to do some lab work and imaging to check for infection.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That's exactly what I was afraid of. How serious could this be?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Infections around joint replacements need to be taken seriously and treated promptly. The good news is you came in early to get this checked out. The doctor will be able to determine the best course of treatment once we get your test results.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. An x ray is needed to confirm placement in rectum. Then IV sedation and analgesia may be used to enable the physician to remove the foreign body in the ED, or he may be admitted for surgery. In this situation, two or more resources are required.

meta.source_case_text: "This is so embarrassing," reports a 29-year-old male. "For the last 12 hours, I have had this thing stuck in my rectum. I have tried and tried to get it out with no success. Can someone help me?" The patient denies abdominal pain or tenderness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pain 4/10.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. An x ray is needed to confirm placement in rectum. Then IV sedation and analgesia may be used to enable the physician to remove the foreign body in the ED, or he may be admitted for surgery. In this situation, two or more resources are required.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: This is so embarrassing... I really don't know how to say this.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Please don't feel embarrassed. I'm here to help, and we see all kinds of medical situations. Whatever it is, we'll take care of you professionally and confidentially.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay... For the last 12 hours, I have had this thing stuck in my rectum. I have tried and tried to get it out with no success. Can someone help me?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand this is uncomfortable to talk about, but you did the right thing coming in. Can you tell me your age first?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 29 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Are you experiencing any abdominal pain or tenderness right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, actually I don't have any belly pain. It's more just uncomfortable and I'm worried about it.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate any pain or discomfort you're feeling right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Maybe about a 4 out of 10. It's not terrible, but it's definitely uncomfortable and I'm really concerned.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Let me check your vital signs. Do you have any medical history, take any medications, or have any allergies I should know about?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I'm pretty healthy. I don't take any medications and I don't have any allergies.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your vital signs all look normal - blood pressure, heart rate, breathing rate, and temperature are all within normal ranges. That's reassuring.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: So what happens now? Can you help me get this out? I'm really embarrassed but I just couldn't get it out myself.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: We can absolutely help you. The doctor will need to examine you and likely order an X-ray to see exactly where the object is positioned. Depending on what they find, they may be able to remove it here in the emergency department.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Will I need to be put to sleep for them to take it out?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That will depend on what the doctor finds on the X-ray and examination. They might use some IV sedation and pain medication to make you more comfortable during the procedure. Let me get you registered and into a private room so we can get you taken care of.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. This elderly patient may have pneumonia. Labs and a chest x ray are required, in addition to IV antibiotics. If vital signs are outside the accepted parameters, they may be considered high risk and meet ESI level-2 criteria.

meta.source_case_text: EMS arrives with a 67-year-old female who lives alone. The patient called 911 because she was too sick to get herself to the doctor. The patient has had a fever and cough for 3 days. She reports coughing up thick green phlegm and is concerned that she has pneumonia. She denies shortness of breath. Past medical history HTN, T 102°F, RR 28, HR 86, BP 140/72, SpO2 94%.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. This elderly patient may have pneumonia. Labs and a chest x ray are required, in addition to IV antibiotics. If vital signs are outside the accepted parameters, they may be considered high risk and meet ESI level-2 criteria.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hello, I'm Sarah, the triage nurse. I see that EMS brought you in today. Can you tell me what's been going on?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I've been feeling terrible for the past 3 days. I live alone, and I got so sick I couldn't even get myself to the doctor, so I had to call 911.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm sorry you're feeling so unwell. Can you describe your symptoms for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I've had this awful fever and a really bad cough. The cough is the worst part - I'm coughing up thick green stuff. I'm worried I might have pneumonia.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That does sound concerning. Are you having any difficulty breathing or shortness of breath?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I'm not short of breath, thank goodness. It's mainly just the fever and this terrible cough with all that green phlegm.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, let me get your vital signs and ask about your medical history. Do you have any ongoing medical conditions or take any medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I have high blood pressure, that's about it. I take medication for that.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Alright, let me check your temperature and other vital signs. Your temperature is quite elevated at 102 degrees, your heart rate is 86, blood pressure is 140 over 72, respiratory rate is 28, and your oxygen saturation is 94 percent.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That fever has been making me feel awful. Is 94 percent oxygen okay?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your oxygen level is a bit on the lower side of normal, and with your symptoms of fever and productive cough, we definitely need to get you evaluated right away. The doctor will likely want to do some blood work and a chest X-ray to check for pneumonia.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I was afraid of that. Will I need to stay in the hospital?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That will depend on what the tests show and how you respond to treatment. Let me get you into a room so we can get started on your evaluation and get you feeling better.

expected.esi_rationale: High risk. The mechanism of injury represents a high-risk situation. His left upper-quadrant pain could be due to a splenic rupture or injury. He may also have a fractured femur, another source of volume loss. This patient's vital signs are stable, so there is no need for immediate lifesaving intervention, but he is at risk for hemorrhagic shock due to volume loss.

meta.source_case_text: EMS arrives with a 14-year-old male who was snowboarding at a nearby ski area, lost control, and ran into a tree. The patient was wearing a ski helmet, is currently aware, alert, and oriented and is complaining of left upper-quadrant pain and left thigh pain. His left femur appears to be broken. BP 112/80, HR 86, RR 14, SpO2 98%, and temperature is normal.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: High risk. The mechanism of injury represents a high-risk situation. His left upper-quadrant pain could be due to a splenic rupture or injury. He may also have a fractured femur, another source of volume loss. This patient's vital signs are stable, so there is no need for immediate lifesaving intervention, but he is at risk for hemorrhagic shock due to volume loss.

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Triage, we're bringing in a 14-year-old male from the ski area. High-energy mechanism - lost control snowboarding and hit a tree head-on.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, what's his current condition? Any obvious injuries?

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: He was wearing a helmet, thankfully. Patient is awake, alert, and oriented. Main complaints are left upper quadrant abdominal pain and left thigh pain. We suspect a fractured left femur - the leg positioning and deformity are consistent with that.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: What are his vital signs?

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: BP 112 over 80, heart rate 86, respiratory rate 14, oxygen saturation 98% on room air, and temperature is normal.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi there, I'm one of the nurses here. Can you tell me your name and how old you are?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm Jake, I'm 14. Man, this really hurts.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you're in pain, Jake. Can you tell me exactly what happened out there?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I was coming down this intermediate run pretty fast, and I guess I caught an edge or something. Next thing I knew I was flying toward this tree and couldn't stop.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That sounds scary. Where exactly does it hurt right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: My left side here, kind of up under my ribs, it's really achy and sore. And my left leg is killing me - I can't move it at all.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate your pain right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: The leg is probably like a 7 or 8. The side pain is maybe a 5 or 6, but it's this deep, weird ache.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Did you hit your head at all? Any dizziness, nausea, or headache?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I had my helmet on. I don't think I hit my head. I'm not dizzy or anything like that.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good, I'm glad you were wearing protection. Any other areas that hurt or feel uncomfortable?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Not really, just those two spots. But the side pain is kind of weird - it's not like when you get the wind knocked out of you. It's deeper.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand. Given the mechanism of your injury and your symptoms, we need to get you evaluated right away. The doctor will want to check for any internal injuries and get some imaging of your leg.

expected.esi_rationale: One resource. It is unknown whether the patient was bitten by the bat because they were sleeping, so postexposure prophylaxis will be initiated. One resource—an intramuscular medication.

meta.source_case_text: "I woke up this morning, and there was a bat flying around our bedroom. Scared me half to death, and now I am so worried about rabies," an anxious 48-year-old female tells you. "My husband opened the window, and the bat flew out." Past medical history of ovarian cysts, no med or allergies, vital signs are within normal limits.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 4: One resource. It is unknown whether the patient was bitten by the bat because they were sleeping, so postexposure prophylaxis will be initiated. One resource—an intramuscular medication.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good morning, I'm the triage nurse. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Oh my goodness, I woke up this morning and there was a bat flying around our bedroom! It scared me half to death, and now I am so worried about rabies.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That does sound frightening. Can you tell me what happened with the bat? Did it have any contact with you?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Well, that's just it - I don't know! I was sleeping, so I have no idea if it bit me or touched me at all. My husband opened the window and the bat flew out, but I'm terrified I might have been exposed to rabies while I was asleep.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I understand your concern. That's actually a very reasonable worry when you've been sleeping in the same room as a bat. Can you confirm your age for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 48 years old.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, and do you have any past medical history I should know about?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I have a history of ovarian cysts, but that's about it. I don't take any regular medications and I don't have any allergies.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. Let me just check your vital signs quickly.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Sure, whatever you need to do. I'm just really anxious about this whole situation.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your vital signs all look normal, which is good. Based on what you've told me about the potential bat exposure while sleeping, the doctor will likely want to start you on rabies post-exposure prophylaxis as a precaution.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Really? Is that necessary? What does that involve?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Yes, because you can't be certain whether you had contact with the bat while sleeping, it's the safest approach. It involves getting an injection today, and it's very effective at preventing rabies if you were exposed.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Okay, if that's what you recommend. I'd rather be safe than sorry with something like rabies.

expected.esi_rationale: The patient is presenting with signs of shock, hypotension tachycardia, and tachypnea. He has a history of HTN and is presenting with signs and symptoms that could be suggestive of a dissecting aortic abdominal aneurysm. On arrival in the emergency department, he will require immediate lifesaving interventions such as immediate IV access, aggressive fluid resuscitation, and perhaps blood prior to surgery.

meta.source_case_text: The family of a 74-year-old male called 911 when he developed severe mid-abdominal pain. "My husband is not a complainer," reports his wife. "The only medication he takes is for high blood pressure." On arrival in the ED, the patient's HR is 140, RR 28, SpO2 94%, BP 72/56.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 1: The patient is presenting with signs of shock, hypotension tachycardia, and tachypnea. He has a history of HTN and is presenting with signs and symptoms that could be suggestive of a dissecting aortic abdominal aneurysm. On arrival in the emergency department, he will require immediate lifesaving interventions such as immediate IV access, aggressive fluid resuscitation, and perhaps blood prior to surgery.

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: We're coming in with a 74-year-old male, severe abdominal pain, altered mental status. Patient is hypotensive and tachycardic. Family called 911 about 20 minutes ago.

conversation.speaker: triage_nurse
conversation.message: Bring him straight to trauma bay 1. What are his current vitals?

conversation.speaker: paramedic
conversation.message: Heart rate 140, blood pressure 72 over 56, respiratory rate 28, SpO2 94% on high-flow oxygen. He's been getting progressively worse during transport.

conversation.speaker: wife
conversation.message: Please help him! He started complaining of terrible stomach pain about an hour ago. My husband never complains about anything - he's tough as nails!

conversation.speaker: triage_nurse
conversation.message: Ma'am, we're going to take excellent care of him. I need you to step back while we get him stabilized. Can you tell me his medical history quickly?

conversation.speaker: wife
conversation.message: He has high blood pressure, that's it. The only medication he takes is for that. He's 74 years old and he was fine this morning!

conversation.speaker: triage_nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. I'm calling for the trauma team and vascular surgery immediately. Sir, can you hear me? Can you tell me where your pain is?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: It hurts... my belly... can't... breathe right...

conversation.speaker: triage_nurse
conversation.message: I know it hurts. We're going to help you right now. Dr. Smith, we need you in trauma 1 immediately. 74-year-old male with severe abdominal pain, hypotensive at 72 over 56, tachycardic at 140.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.message: On my way. Get two large bore IVs started immediately, type and crossmatch for 6 units of blood, and call vascular surgery stat. This could be a ruptured AAA.

conversation.speaker: triage_nurse
conversation.message: Already calling vascular. Patient's oxygen saturation is dropping to 94% despite high-flow oxygen. His skin is cool and mottled.

conversation.speaker: wife
conversation.message: Is he going to be okay? What's happening to him?

conversation.speaker: triage_nurse
conversation.message: Ma'am, your husband is very sick and we're doing everything we can. This is a medical emergency and he needs immediate surgery. The surgical team is on their way.

expected.esi_rationale: No resources. Following a physical exam, this patient will be discharged to home with a prescription and appropriate discharge instructions. No resources are required.

meta.source_case_text: "I woke up this morning, and my eyes are all red and crusty," reports a 29-year-old kindergarten teacher. "I think I got it from the kids at school," she tells you. She denies pain or other visual disturbances. Her vital signs are within normal limits.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 5: No resources. Following a physical exam, this patient will be discharged to home with a prescription and appropriate discharge instructions. No resources are required.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Jennifer, the triage nurse. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, I woke up this morning, and my eyes are all red and crusty. It's really bothering me.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see that your eyes do look quite red. Can you tell me a bit about yourself - your age and what you do for work?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'm 29 years old and I'm a kindergarten teacher. I think I got it from the kids at school - you know how kids are always getting sick and passing things around.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's very possible - conjunctivitis is quite common in school settings. Are you experiencing any pain in your eyes or any problems with your vision?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, there's no pain really. My vision seems fine, it's just the redness and the crusty discharge that's bothering me.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, let me get your vital signs to make sure everything else is normal.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your vital signs are all within normal limits - temperature, blood pressure, heart rate all look good. This appears to be a straightforward case of conjunctivitis.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Is that contagious? I'm supposed to go back to work tomorrow and I don't want to spread it to my students.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's a great question and shows you're being responsible about your students' health. The doctor will examine your eyes and determine if this is bacterial or viral conjunctivitis, and give you guidance about when it's safe to return to work.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Thank you. How long do you think I'll need to wait? I know this isn't an emergency compared to other patients.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You're right that this isn't urgent, but we'll get you seen reasonably quickly. The doctor will likely be able to prescribe some eye drops and give you instructions for treatment and when you can safely return to the classroom.

expected.esi_rationale: Two or more resources. Based on the mechanism of injury, this patient will require an x ray of his clavicle and suturing of his arm laceration. In addition, he may need a tetanus booster, but that does not count as a resource. If the mechanism of injury was higher, the patient could meet ESI level-2 criteria, high risk. The patient's pain rating is 8/10, but the triage nurse can intervene by applying a sling and providing ice to decrease the pain and swelling.

He lost control of his bike when he hit a pothole. He has a 2-centimeter laceration on his arm and pain over his left clavicle. Vital signs: T 97.4°F, RR 18, HR 62, BP 122/70, SpO2 100%. Pain 6/10.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 3: Two or more resources. Based on the mechanism of injury, this patient will require an x ray of his clavicle and suturing of his arm laceration. In addition, he may need a tetanus booster, but that does not count as a resource. If the mechanism of injury was higher, the patient could meet ESI level-2 criteria, high risk. The patient's pain rating is 8/10, but the triage nurse can intervene by applying a sling and providing ice to decrease the pain and swelling.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi there, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I was in a bicycle accident about an hour ago. Without the helmet, I would have been really hurt, but I'm still pretty banged up.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm glad you were wearing a helmet! Can you tell me what happened during the accident?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I was riding my bike and lost control when I hit a pothole. I went down pretty hard on my left side.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I can see you have some injuries. Can you show me where you're hurt?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yeah, I have this cut on my arm that's been bleeding, and my left shoulder and collarbone area really hurt.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Let me take a look at that cut. It appears to be about 2 centimeters long on your arm. Are you experiencing any pain in your left clavicle area?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Yes, right here over my left clavicle. It's pretty sore when I move my arm.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain you've ever experienced, how would you rate your pain right now?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: I'd say it's about a 6 out of 10. It's definitely uncomfortable.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm going to check your vital signs now. Can you tell me if you have any other medical conditions or take any medications?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: No, I'm pretty healthy. I don't take any medications and don't have any medical problems.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good. Your vital signs look stable - temperature is 97.4, respiratory rate 18, heart rate 62, blood pressure 122 over 70, and your oxygen saturation is 100%. When was your last tetanus shot?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Um, I'm not really sure. Maybe when I was in high school? It's been several years for sure.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Okay, we'll likely need to give you a tetanus booster since it's been more than 5 years. Based on your injuries, the doctor will probably want to get an X-ray of your clavicle to make sure there's no fracture, and that cut on your arm will need to be cleaned and sutured.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That sounds reasonable. How long do you think it will take?

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: You'll need a couple of different treatments, so you'll be with us for a few hours. Let me get you registered and we'll get you back to see the doctor. I can also get you some ice for that shoulder to help with pain and swelling.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: That would be great, thank you. The ice sounds really good right now.

expected.esi_rationale: Severe pain or distress. This patient needs to be taken to a safe, quiet room within the emergency department. Her medical, emotional, and legal needs must be addressed in a timely manner.

meta.source_case_text: When asked why she came to the emergency department, the 18-year-old college student begins to cry. She tells the triage nurse that she was sexually assaulted last night at an off-campus party.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 2: Severe pain or distress. This patient needs to be taken to a safe, quiet room within the emergency department. Her medical, emotional, and legal needs must be addressed in a timely manner.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Hi there, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses here. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: *begins to cry* I... I don't know where else to go. Something happened to me last night.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: It's okay, you're safe here. Take your time. Can you tell me a little bit about what happened?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: *crying* I was at this party last night, an off-campus party. I... I was sexually assaulted.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: I'm so sorry that happened to you. You were very brave to come in today. I'm going to make sure we get you the help and care you need. Can you confirm your age for me?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: *wiping tears* I'm 18. I'm a college student here.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Thank you. I want you to know that we have specialized staff here who are trained to help in situations like this. We're going to take you to a safe, quiet room where you can have privacy and we can address your medical and emotional needs.

expected.esi_rationale: Requires immediate lifesaving interventions. From the history, it sounds like the hockey player experienced a disruption in the electrical activity in his heart due to the blow to the chest from the hockey puck. He will require immediate lifesaving interventions to address airway, breathing, and circulation. This patient is intubated, which meets criteria for lifesaving interventions.

meta.source_case_text: A 16-year-old high school hockey player collapsed on the ice after being hit in the anterior chest by the puck. The coaching staff began CPR almost immediately, and he was defibrillated three times with a return of spontaneous circulation. He arrives in the emergency department intubated.
meta.source_answer_text: ESI level 1: Requires immediate lifesaving interventions. From the history, it sounds like the hockey player experienced a disruption in the electrical activity in his heart due to the blow to the chest from the hockey puck. He will require immediate lifesaving interventions to address airway, breathing, and circulation. This patient is intubated, which meets criteria for lifesaving interventions.

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: Trauma bay, incoming code blue! 16-year-old male, post-cardiac arrest from blunt chest trauma during hockey game. Puck to the anterior chest, immediate collapse on ice.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Copy that, trauma team is standing by. What's his current status?

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: Coaching staff started CPR immediately on scene. We defibrillated him three times before we got return of spontaneous circulation. He's currently intubated and on the monitor.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Current vitals and rhythm?

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: Heart rate 110, blood pressure 95 over 60, oxygen saturation 98% on the ventilator. He's in normal sinus rhythm now, but we had to shock him out of V-fib multiple times.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Any response to stimuli? Pupils reactive?

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: Pupils are equal and reactive. He's sedated but was moving extremities before we gave him the midazolam. No obvious injuries other than the chest impact.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: ETA to trauma bay?

conversation.speaker: ems
conversation.message: Rolling in now. This looks like commotio cordis - direct impact to the chest during the vulnerable period of cardiac cycle.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Understood. Trauma team, cardiology, and ICU are all notified. We're ready for immediate resuscitation protocols.

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Good afternoon, I'm Jennifer, one of the triage nurses. What brings you to the emergency department today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.message: Hi, this morning I stepped on a rusty nail and it went right through my shoe into my foot. I washed it really well when I got home, but I read on the Internet that I need a tetanus shot.

conversation.message: That's smart of you to get that checked out. Can you tell me a bit more about what happened? Where exactly did this occur?

conversation.message: I was walking through a construction area near my apartment this morning and didn't see the nail sticking up from a board. It went right through the sole of my sneaker and into the bottom of my foot.

conversation.speaker: patient

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: That's good wound care. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? Any previous surgeries or allergies?

conversation.speaker: patient

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Let me take your vital signs and then we'll have the doctor examine your foot. You're right that a tetanus booster is recommended for puncture wounds like this, especially from rusty metal.

conversation.speaker: patient

conversation.speaker: nurse
conversation.message: Your vital signs are all normal, which is great. Since this isn't an urgent situation, there may be a bit of a wait, but the doctor will examine your wound and get you that tetanus shot. You did the right thing coming in.

conversation.speaker: Triage Nurse
conversation.message: Sarah, can you tell me about the pills you took? When did you take them?

conversation.message: About 30 minutes ago, maybe a little longer. I took a whole bunch of Tylenol... more than 30 I think. My boyfriend Jake broke up with me this morning and I just... I didn't know what else to do.

conversation.message: I understand you're hurting right now. Do you have any medical conditions or take any regular medications?

conversation.speaker: Triage Nurse

conversation.message: Am I going to be okay? I'm scared now.

conversation.speaker: Triage Nurse
conversation.message: We're going to take very good care of you. The doctor will see you immediately, and we have treatments that work well when we catch this early like we did.
